title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways



Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. It is a vector quantity.
Average Acceleration (\(\bar{a} = \Delta v / \Delta t\)) describes the overall change in velocity over a time interval.
Instantaneous Acceleration (\(a(t) = dv(t)/dt = d^2x(t)/dt^2\)) describes the acceleration at a specific moment.
On a velocity-time graph, instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent line.



Acceleration occurs when velocity changes magnitude, direction, or both.
If velocity and acceleration have the same sign, the object is speeding up.
If velocity and acceleration have opposite signs, the object is slowing down.
The term “deceleration” is avoided in favor of precise vector description.



These key takeaways summarize the core concepts of acceleration. Remember the vector nature of acceleration and its relationship to both position and velocity through derivatives.

title: Physics
text:
Challenge Problem: Rocket Launch Dynamics
An experimental rocket is launched vertically. Its upward velocity is described by the function:
\(v(t) = (100 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2\) where \(t\) is in seconds.

Calculate the instantaneous acceleration of the rocket at \(t = 3 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 15 \text{ s}\).
Determine the average acceleration of the rocket during the time interval from \(t = 0 \text{ s}\) to \(t = 10 \text{ s}\).
At what time does the rocket reach its maximum upward velocity, and what is this velocity?


Here’s a problem that ties together everything we’ve learned. You’ll need to use differentiation for instantaneous acceleration and maximum velocity, and the average acceleration formula for part 2. Pay attention to units and signs!

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Rocket Launch Dynamics (1/2)
1. Instantaneous Acceleration \(a(t) = dv/dt\)
First, find the acceleration function: \(a(t) = \frac{d}{dt} ((100 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2)\) \(a(t) = (100 \text{ m/s}^2) - (10 \text{ m/s}^3)t\)
Now, calculate at specific times: - At \(t = 3 \text{ s}\): \(a(3 \text{ s}) = 100 - 10(3) = 100 - 30 = \mathbf{70 \text{ m/s}^2}\) - At \(t = 15 \text{ s}\): \(a(15 \text{ s}) = 100 - 10(15) = 100 - 150 = \mathbf{-50 \text{ m/s}^2}\)

For instantaneous acceleration, we differentiate the velocity function. Notice that at 3 seconds, the acceleration is positive (still speeding up), but at 15 seconds, it’s negative. This means the rocket has passed its peak velocity and is now slowing down, or possibly starting to fall back to Earth, if it were not for the initial direction constraint.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Rocket Launch Dynamics (2/2)
2. Average Acceleration from \(t = 0 \text{ s}\) to \(t = 10 \text{ s}\)
First, find velocities at \(t_0 = 0 \text{ s}\) and \(t_f = 10 \text{ s}\): \(v(0 \text{ s}) = 100(0) - 5(0)^2 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) \(v(10 \text{ s}) = 100(10) - 5(10)^2 = 1000 - 5(100) = 1000 - 500 = 500 \text{ m/s}\)
Now, calculate average acceleration: \(\bar{a} = \frac{v(10 \text{ s}) - v(0 \text{ s})}{10 \text{ s} - 0 \text{ s}} = \frac{500 \text{ m/s} - 0 \text{ m/s}}{10 \text{ s}} = \mathbf{50 \text{ m/s}^2}\)
3. Maximum Upward Velocity
Maximum velocity occurs when acceleration is zero (\(a(t) = 0\)). \(a(t) = 100 - 10t = 0\) \(10t = 100 \implies t = \mathbf{10 \text{ s}}\)
Now, substitute \(t=10 \text{ s}\) into the velocity function to find the maximum velocity: \(v_{max} = v(10 \text{ s}) = 100(10) - 5(10)^2 = 1000 - 500 = \mathbf{500 \text{ m/s}}\)

For average acceleration, we just need the velocities at the start and end of the interval. For maximum velocity, the key insight is that the derivative (acceleration) must be zero at a maximum or minimum. Solving for ‘t’ when a(t)=0 gives us the time of maximum velocity, which we then plug back into the velocity equation to find the maximum speed. This problem illustrates how instantaneous and average accelerations can differ and how calculus is essential for analyzing dynamic systems in engineering.

title: Physics
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this section, you will be able to:

Use the kinematic equations with the variables y and g to analyze free-fall motion.
Describe how the values of the position, velocity, and acceleration change during a free fall.
Solve for the position, velocity, and acceleration as functions of time when an object is in a free fall.


These objectives will equip you to tackle a wide range of problems involving objects moving vertically under gravity. We’ll refine our use of kinematic equations specifically for this scenario.

title: Physics
text:
What is Free Fall?

Free fall describes the motion of an object falling solely under the influence of gravity.
Key assumptions:

Air resistance is negligible.
Friction is negligible.
Motion is one-dimensional (straight up and down).

“Falling” doesn’t necessarily mean moving downwards. An object thrown upward is also in free fall once released.
The instant an object leaves contact with whatever held or threw it, it is in free fall.
Once it hits the ground or another object, it is no longer in free fall.


Think of it as pure gravitational motion. The moment you let go of something, or throw it, gravity is the only significant force influencing its vertical motion. We often simplify by neglecting air resistance for these early calculations, which is reasonable for dense objects over short distances.

title: Physics
text:
Acceleration Due to Gravity (\(g\))

The constant acceleration of free-falling objects is called acceleration due to gravity.
Its magnitude is denoted by \(g\).
On Earth’s surface, the average value is: \[ g = 9.81 \text{ m/s}^2 \quad (\text{or } 32.2 \text{ ft/s}^2) \]
For simplicity, we will use \(g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\) unless specified otherwise.
The direction of acceleration due to gravity is always downward (towards the center of Earth). This direction defines “vertical.”







Important


The sign of \(g\) in kinematic equations depends on your chosen coordinate system:

If upward is positive, then \(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\).
If downward is positive, then \(a = +g = +9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\). Choose a consistent coordinate system and stick to it!





The choice of positive direction is arbitrary but consistency is key. Most problems default to upward as positive, so ‘g’ often appears with a negative sign.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equations for Free Fall (Vertical Motion)
text:
Kinematic Equations for Free Fall (Vertical Motion)
We adapt our constant acceleration equations for vertical motion, using \(y\) for displacement and \(a = -g\) (assuming upward is positive).

Velocity-Time Relation: \[ \mathbf{v = v_0 - gt} \]
Position-Time Relation: \[ \mathbf{y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2} \]
Velocity-Position Relation (Time-Independent): \[ \mathbf{v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)} \]







Tip


General Problem-Solving Strategy for Free Fall:

Choose a Coordinate System: Define origin (\(y_0=0\)) and positive direction (e.g., upward).
Sketch the Problem: Visualize initial/final positions, velocities, and acceleration.
List Knowns & Unknowns: Pay attention to initial conditions (e.g., “dropped from rest” means \(v_0=0\)).
Select Equations: Choose the kinematic equation(s) that best fit your knowns and unknowns.





These are simply our familiar kinematic equations, but with x replaced by y and a replaced by -g (because we are setting upward as the positive direction). This standardization helps avoid confusion. The problem-solving strategy remains the same as for horizontal motion, with an added emphasis on establishing your vertical coordinate system clearly.

title: Physics
section: Example 3.14: Free Fall of a Ball
text:
Example 3.14: Free Fall of a Ball
A ball is thrown downward from the top of a \(98 \text{ m}\) high building with an initial velocity of \(4.9 \text{ m/s}\) downward.

How much time elapses before the ball reaches the ground?
What is the velocity when it arrives at the ground?



Strategy:

Coordinate System:

Origin at the top of the building (\(y_0 = 0\)).
Positive direction upward.

Knowns:

\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
\(v_0 = -4.9 \text{ m/s}\) (downward is negative)
\(y = -98 \text{ m}\) (ground is 98m below origin)
\(g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2 \implies a = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\)

Unknowns:

\(t\) (time to ground)
\(v\) (final velocity)






Ball thrown downward from a tall building.


Figure 3.27: Positions and velocities at 1-s intervals.


This problem is a good test of coordinate system consistency. By choosing upward as positive, both the initial velocity and the final position (ground level) will be negative, and naturally, ‘g’ will be negative in the equations. The figure helps visualize the scenario.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part 1/2)
text:
Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part 1/2)
1. Time to reach the ground (\(t\))
Using \(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\):
\[ -98.0 = 0 + (-4.9)t - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2 \] \[ -98.0 = -4.9t - 4.9t^2 \] Rearrange into a quadratic equation: \[ 4.9t^2 + 4.9t - 98.0 = 0 \] Divide by 4.9: \[ t^2 + t - 20 = 0 \] Factor or use quadratic formula \((t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a})\): \[ (t + 5)(t - 4) = 0 \] Solutions: \(t = -5 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 4 \text{ s}\).
Since time cannot be negative in this context, we choose: \[ t = \mathbf{4.0 \text{ s}} \]

We use the position-time equation because it contains ‘y’, ‘y0’, ‘v0’, ‘g’, and ‘t’. Solving the quadratic equation gives two mathematical solutions. We must apply physical reasoning to choose the correct one: time cannot be negative from the moment of release. The negative root simply represents a time before the ball was released, if its trajectory had been extended backward.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part 2/2)
text:
Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part 2/2)
2. Velocity when it arrives at the ground (\(v\))
Using \(v = v_0 - gt\) with \(t = 4.0 \text{ s}\):
\[ v = -4.9 \text{ m/s} - (9.8 \text{ m/s}^2)(4.0 \text{ s}) \] \[ v = -4.9 \text{ m/s} - 39.2 \text{ m/s} \] \[ v = \mathbf{-44.1 \text{ m/s}} \]
Significance:

The negative sign for velocity confirms the ball is moving downward when it hits the ground.
It’s important to remember that motion stops being “free fall” as soon as the ball makes contact with the ground.
Consistency in the chosen coordinate system (upward positive) is crucial for correct sign conventions.


The final velocity is negative, which is consistent with our coordinate system (upward positive, downward negative) and indicates the ball is indeed traveling downward. This also gives us a sense of the speed the ball is moving at impact, which is important in engineering for structural design, impact testing, and safety considerations.

title: Physics
section: Example 3.15: Vertical Motion of a Baseball
text:
Example 3.15: Vertical Motion of a Baseball
A batter hits a baseball straight upward. It is caught \(5.0 \text{ s}\) later at the same location from which it was hit (\(y_0 = y = 0\)).

What is the initial velocity of the ball?
What is the maximum height the ball reaches?
How long does it take to reach the maximum height?
What is the acceleration at the top of its path?
What is the velocity of the ball when it is caught?



Strategy:

Coordinate System:

Origin at the hit/catch location (\(y_0 = 0\)).
Positive direction upward.

Knowns:

\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
\(y = 0 \text{ m}\) (when caught)
\(t_{\text{total}} = 5.0 \text{ s}\)
\(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\)

Key Insight: At maximum height, \(v = 0\).





Baseball hit straight upward and caught.


Figure 3.28: A baseball hit straight up is caught 5.0 s later.


This example addresses common misconceptions about free fall, particularly concerning the velocity and acceleration at the peak of the trajectory. Since the ball is caught at the same height it was hit, we know the total flight time. The key is to remember that at its maximum height, its instantaneous vertical velocity is zero.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 1/3)
text:
Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 1/3)
1. Initial Velocity of the Ball (\(v_0\))
Using \(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) with \(y_0=0\), \(y=0\), and \(t=5.0 \text{ s}\):
\[ 0 = 0 + v_0(5.0) - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)(5.0)^2 \]
\[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - 4.9(25.0) \]
\[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - 122.5 \]
\[ 5.0v_0 = 122.5 \]
\[ v_0 = \frac{122.5}{5.0} = \mathbf{24.5 \text{ m/s}} \]
2. Maximum Height the Ball Reaches (\(y_{\text{max}}\))
At maximum height, \(v = 0\). Using \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\) with \(y_0=0\):
\[ 0^2 = (24.5)^2 - 2(9.8)(y_{\text{max}} - 0) \]
\[ 0 = 600.25 - 19.6y_{\text{max}} \]
\[ 19.6y_{\text{max}} = 600.25 \]
\[ y_{\text{max}} = \frac{600.25}{19.6} = \mathbf{30.6 \text{ m}} \]

First, we find the initial velocity using the total flight time and the fact that the ball returns to its starting height. Then, knowing the initial velocity, we can find the maximum height by setting the final velocity to zero in the time-independent equation.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 2/3)
text:
Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 2/3)
3. Time to Reach Maximum Height (\(t_{\text{max}}\))
At maximum height, \(v = 0\). Using \(v = v_0 - gt\):
\[ 0 = 24.5 - 9.8t_{\text{max}} \]
\[ 9.8t_{\text{max}} = 24.5 \]
\[ t_{\text{max}} = \frac{24.5}{9.8} = \mathbf{2.5 \text{ s}} \]
(Note: This is exactly half the total flight time, as expected for symmetric motion.)
4. Acceleration at the Top of Its Path (\(a_{\text{top}}\))
The acceleration due to gravity is constant throughout the entire flight.
So, at the top of its path, \(a = \mathbf{-9.8 \text{ m/s}^2}\).
(Even though \(v=0\), velocity is changing from positive to negative, so acceleration is non-zero).

The time to reach maximum height can be found from the first kinematic equation. It’s often useful to note that for symmetric free fall motion, the time to reach the peak is half the total flight time. The answer to question 4 is crucial: acceleration due to gravity never changes during free fall, even when the instantaneous velocity is zero at the peak. The object is still under the influence of gravity and its velocity is continuously changing.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 3/3)
text:
Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part 3/3)
5. Velocity of the Ball When It Is Caught (\(v_{\text{catch}}\))
Using \(v = v_0 - gt\) with \(t = 5.0 \text{ s}\):
\[ v_{\text{catch}} = 24.5 \text{ m/s} - (9.8 \text{ m/s}^2)(5.0 \text{ s}) \]
\[ v_{\text{catch}} = 24.5 \text{ m/s} - 49.0 \text{ m/s} \]
\[ v_{\text{catch}} = \mathbf{-24.5 \text{ m/s}} \]
Significance:

The final velocity is the negative of the initial velocity, confirming the ball returns with the same speed but in the opposite direction.
This problem demonstrates that free fall equations apply to both upward and downward parts of the trajectory.


The final velocity is the negative of the initial velocity, which is a hallmark of symmetric free-fall trajectories. This example reinforces the understanding that “free fall” applies to the entire motion once launched, not just the downward part.

title: Physics
section: Check Your Understanding: Falling Ice Chunk
text:
Check Your Understanding: Falling Ice Chunk
A chunk of ice breaks off a glacier and falls \(30.0 \text{ m}\) before it hits the water. Assuming it falls freely (no air resistance).

How long does it take to hit the water?
Which quantity increases faster, the speed of the ice chunk or its distance traveled?







Tip


Hint for Part 2: Think about the functional form of speed (\(v\) vs \(t\)) and distance (\(y\) vs \(t\)).




This is a straightforward free-fall problem. For part 2, remember the equations that describe speed and distance as functions of time. One of them grows linearly with time, and the other grows quadratically.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Falling Ice Chunk
1. Time to Hit the Water (\(t\))
Coordinate System: Let \(y_0 = 0\) at the glacier edge, and positive direction downward.
Then \(a = +g = +9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\).
Knowns:
\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\)
\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (starts from rest)
\(y = 30.0 \text{ m}\) (displacement downward)
\(a = +9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\)
Equation: \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
\[ 30.0 = 0 + 0 \cdot t + \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2 \]
\[ 30.0 = 4.9t^2 \]
\[ t^2 = \frac{30.0}{4.9} \approx 6.122 \]
\[ t = \sqrt{6.122} \approx \mathbf{2.47 \text{ s}} \]
2. Comparing Speed and Distance Traveled

Speed: \(v = v_0 + at \implies v = gt\) (since \(v_0=0\)). Speed increases linearly with time (\(v \propto t\)).
Distance Traveled: \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \implies y = \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) (since \(y_0=0, v_0=0\)). Distance increases quadratically with time (\(y \propto t^2\)).

Therefore, the distance traveled increases faster than the speed of the ice chunk.

Using a downward positive coordinate system simplifies the sign of ‘g’. The time to fall 30 meters is just under 2.5 seconds. For part 2, it’s a conceptual question about the functional forms. Distance grows quadratically with time (t-squared), while speed grows linearly with time. So, as time progresses, the distance covered increases much more rapidly. This is a common characteristic of constantly accelerated motion.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Free fall is motion solely under gravity, neglecting air resistance.
All objects in free fall accelerate at \(g = 9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\) (downward) near Earth’s surface, regardless of mass.
The kinematic equations for constant acceleration apply, with y for displacement and a = ±g (depending on coordinate system).
A consistent coordinate system (e.g., upward positive) is critical for correctly handling signs of velocity, displacement, and acceleration.
At the peak of vertical trajectory, velocity is momentarily zero, but acceleration is still g (downward).
Objects returning to their starting height have the same speed but opposite velocity direction.


These are the core principles for understanding free fall. Engineering applications range from designing amusement park rides to analyzing projectile trajectories.

title: Chapter 3: Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Position and Frame of Reference
Position (x): Location of an object at a particular time relative to a frame of reference.


Frame of reference is crucial. For engineering applications, we might use Earth, a moving vehicle, or a robotic arm as our reference frame depending on the context.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Displacement: Change in Position
When an object moves, its position changes. This change is called displacement.



Displacement (\(\boldsymbol{\Delta x}\)): The change in an object’s position.
Implies an object has moved, or been “displaced.”
Vector quantity: It has both magnitude and direction.

Can be positive or negative depending on the chosen positive direction.

Calculated as the final position minus the initial position.





Displacement is a core concept. It’s not just about how far you’ve gone, but also in what direction. If I walk 5 meters forward and then 5 meters backward to my starting point, my displacement is zero, even though I’ve walked a total of 10 meters. This distinction is vital in many engineering contexts, like calculating the final position of a robotic arm after a series of movements, where the net change from its starting point is important.

title: Chapter 3: Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Multiple Displacements
Total displacement is the sum of individual displacements:
\[\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = \sum \Delta x_i\]
Example: Professor moves +2 m, then -4 m

\(\Delta x_1 = 2 - 0 = 2\) m
\(\Delta x_2 = -2 - 2 = -4\) m
\(\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = 2 + (-4) = -2\) m


The sign convention matters! Positive/negative directions must be clearly defined at the start of any problem.

title: Chapter 3: Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Distance vs. Displacement


Distance Traveled - Total path length - Always positive - Scalar quantity
\[x_{\text{Total}} = \sum |\Delta x_i|\]

Displacement - Change in position - Can be positive/negative - Vector quantity
\[\Delta x_{\text{Total}} = \sum \Delta x_i\]







Important


Key Difference: Distance is path-dependent; displacement depends only on start and end points.

title: Chapter 3: Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Average Velocity
Average velocity is displacement divided by elapsed time:
\[\bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_2 - x_1}{t_2 - t_1}\]

Vector quantity (direction matters)
Can be positive or negative
SI units: m/s


Average velocity gives the constant speed needed to go directly from start to finish in the given time.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Position, Displacement, and Average Velocity
An Engineering Physics Perspective

Welcome to this session on kinematics, focusing on position, displacement, and average velocity. These fundamental concepts are crucial for understanding the motion of objects in engineering applications.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Describing Motion: Where Are You?
To describe an object’s motion, we first need its position.



Position (\(\boldsymbol{x}\)): Where an object is located at a particular time.
Always specified relative to a frame of reference.

A convenient set of axes from which motion is described.
Example: Rocket relative to Earth; cyclist relative to buildings.

For one-dimensional motion, we often use variable \(\boldsymbol{x}\) (horizontal) or \(\boldsymbol{y}\) (vertical).





Think about motion in your daily life. The most basic question is, “Where am I?” In physics, this is ‘position’. But position isn’t absolute; it’s always relative to something else, which we call a frame of reference. This is crucial in engineering, for instance, when designing navigation systems for autonomous vehicles or drones, where the reference frame might be global GPS coordinates or local sensors.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Calculating Displacement
The change in position, \(\Delta x\), is defined as:
\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_0 \]

\(\boldsymbol{\Delta x}\): displacement
\(\boldsymbol{x_f}\): final position
\(\boldsymbol{x_0}\): initial position







Note


Key Point: The Greek letter Delta (\(\Delta\)) always means “change in” a quantity. So, \(\Delta x\) is “change in x”.




SI Unit: Meters (m).

Be mindful of unit conversions (e.g., kilometers to meters, feet to meters) in problems, especially when working with international standards or hybrid systems.



The formula itself is straightforward: final minus initial. It’s critical to pay attention to the signs. If you define right as positive, then movement to the left will result in a negative displacement. This simple equation forms the basis for understanding more complex kinematic equations. Always double-check your units! In engineering, unit consistency is paramount to avoid costly errors.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Total Displacement vs. Distance Traveled
These two terms are often confused but have distinct meanings.


Total Displacement (\(\boldsymbol{\Delta x_{Total}}\))

The net change in position from start to end.
Vector sum of individual displacements.
Formula: \[ \Delta x_{Total} = \sum \Delta x_i \]
Can be positive, negative, or zero.
Magnitude is \(|\Delta x_{Total}|\).


Total Distance Traveled (\(\boldsymbol{x_{Total}}\))

The entire length of the path covered.
Scalar sum of the magnitudes of individual displacements.
Formula: \[ x_{Total} = \sum |\Delta x_i| \]
Always positive or zero.
No direction associated.



Imagine driving a car. If you leave home, run errands, and return home, your displacement might be zero, but your odometer will show the total distance traveled, which is definitely not zero. In engineering, total displacement might be important for verifying the final position of a robot arm or a component, while distance traveled might be critical for calculating fuel consumption, maintenance schedules, or wear and tear on components and tracks.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Introducing Average Velocity
To fully describe motion, we must also consider time.

The time variable allows us to quantify how fast an object is moving.
Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\)): The rate at which position changes over a period of time.
It is a vector quantity.

Can be positive or negative.

Elapsed Time (\(\Delta t\)): The time taken to travel between two points.







Note


Average velocity describes the overall rate of change, not necessarily the speed at any given instant.




If an object changes position, it took some time to do so. Average velocity combines these two concepts: displacement and elapsed time. Think of it as the average speed and direction you would have needed to maintain to cover the displacement in the given time.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Calculating Average Velocity
The formula for average velocity is:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\text{Displacement between two points}}{\text{Time needed to make the displacement}} \]
Or, more formally:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_0}{t_f - t_0} \]

\(\boldsymbol{\bar{v}}\): average velocity
\(\boldsymbol{\Delta x}\): displacement
\(\boldsymbol{\Delta t}\): elapsed time







Tip


Units: The standard SI unit for average velocity is meters per second (m/s). Ensure consistent units throughout your calculations; converting all quantities to base SI units early is often a good practice.




This formula tells us the average rate of change of position. If the velocity is constant, then this is the exact velocity. If not, it’s an average over the given time interval. For instance, in traffic engineering, average velocity might be used to analyze traffic flow over a segment of highway, even if individual cars are constantly changing their speed. It helps in understanding overall system performance rather than instantaneous conditions.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Instantaneous Velocity and Speed

Good morning/afternoon, everyone. Today, we’re diving deeper into motion by exploring instantaneous velocity and speed. Unlike average velocity, which gives us an overall picture, instantaneous velocity tells us precisely how fast and in what direction an object is moving at any given moment. This concept is fundamental, especially when designing systems that require precise control and analysis of motion, such as robotics or aerospace engineering.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Beyond Average: Instantaneous Velocity
While average velocity describes motion over an interval, instantaneous velocity tells us how fast an object is moving at a specific point in time.



Instantaneous Velocity (\(\boldsymbol{v(t)}\)): The velocity of an object at any single point along its path.

Often simply called velocity.

Conceptually, it’s the average velocity between two points as the time interval between them approaches zero.
This is where calculus becomes essential for precision.


\[ v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{x(t + \Delta t) - x(t)}{\Delta t} \]







Note


Why is this important? In engineering, knowing the instantaneous velocity is crucial for collision avoidance systems, predicting projectile trajectories, or precisely controlling machining tools, where the state at every moment matters.




Imagine a car speedometer. It doesn’t tell you your average speed for the entire trip; it tells you your speed right now. That’s instantaneous speed. Instantaneous velocity adds direction to that. The mathematical definition shows this as a limit, which directly leads us to a fundamental concept in calculus.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Instantaneous Velocity: The Derivative
Mathematically, instantaneous velocity is the derivative of position with respect to time.
\[ v(t) = \frac{d}{dt} x(t) \]

\(\boldsymbol{v(t)}\): Instantaneous velocity as a function of time.
\(\boldsymbol{x(t)}\): Position as a function of time.
The instantaneous velocity at a specific time \(\boldsymbol{t_0}\) is the slope of the tangent line to the position function \(x(t)\) at that time \(\boldsymbol{t_0}\).







Important


Graphical Interpretation On a position-time graph, the instantaneous velocity is represented by the slope of the line tangent to the curve at a particular point.




This equation is a cornerstone of kinematics. If you have a mathematical expression for an object’s position as it changes over time, taking its derivative gives you its velocity at any instant. This concept is fundamental in many engineering disciplines, such as calculating the stress on a component due to rapid changes in velocity, or designing shock absorbers.

text:
Visualizing Instantaneous Velocity


This graph beautifully illustrates the concept. The average velocity between two points is the slope of the secant line connecting them. As the time interval shrinks, the secant line approaches the tangent line, and its slope becomes the instantaneous velocity. Notice at time \(t_0\), where the position function reaches its peak, the tangent line is horizontal, meaning the instantaneous velocity is zero. This signifies a momentary stop or reversal of direction.

section: Velocity vs. Speed: A Critical Distinction
text:
Velocity vs. Speed: A Critical Distinction
In physics and engineering, velocity and speed are NOT interchangeable.


Velocity (\(\boldsymbol{v}\))

Vector quantity: has both magnitude and direction.

Can be positive, negative, or zero.

Describes how fast an object is moving AND in which direction.
Instantaneous velocity is \(\boldsymbol{v(t) = \frac{dx}{dt}}\).
Average velocity uses displacement.


Speed (\(\boldsymbol{s}\))

Scalar quantity: has only magnitude (how fast), no direction.

Always positive or zero.

Instantaneous speed is the magnitude of the instantaneous velocity: \(\boldsymbol{s(t) = |v(t)|}\).
Average speed uses total distance traveled. \[ \text{Average speed} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Elapsed time}} \]



This distinction is vital for engineers. For example, a robotic arm might need to achieve a certain velocity for precise placement, but its maximum speed might be limited by motor capacity. Or, when considering fuel efficiency, you care about the average speed of a vehicle over a journey, but for traffic safety, you need to know the instantaneous velocity of all vehicles.

title: Physics
text:
Calculating Instantaneous Velocity with Calculus
When the position function x(t) is given mathematically, we use differentiation to find v(t).

For polynomial position functions, x(t) often consists of terms in the form of At^n.
We use the power rule of differentiation: \[ \frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = An \cdot t^{n-1} \]
If x(t) has multiple terms added or subtracted, differentiate each term separately and sum the results.


The power rule is a cornerstone of calculus in physics. Make sure you’re comfortable with it. A is a constant coefficient, n is an integer power. Remember that the derivative of a constant term is zero, and the derivative of At (where n=1) is simply A.

text:
Engineering Challenge: Autonomous Vehicle Trajectory
A prototype autonomous vehicle’s position along a straight test track is given by the function:
\[ x(t) = (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 + (4.0 \text{ m/s})t \]
where \(x\) is in meters and \(t\) is in seconds.
Problem: 1. Calculate the instantaneous velocity function \(v(t)\) for the vehicle. 2. Determine the instantaneous velocity and speed of the vehicle at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 5.0 \text{ s}\). 3. Find the time(s) when the vehicle is momentarily at rest.

This problem represents a common engineering task: analyzing the motion of an autonomous system. Understanding its velocity profile is essential for trajectory planning, control system design, and safety protocols. Take a few minutes to work through these calculations, applying the differentiation rules we just discussed.

Solution: Autonomous Vehicle Trajectory
Let’s solve the problem step-by-step.
Given: \(x(t) = 0.5t^3 - 3.0t^2 + 4.0t\) (units omitted for brevity, assuming SI units)
1. Calculate the instantaneous velocity function \(\boldsymbol{v(t)}\): Apply the power rule for differentiation: \[ v(t) = \frac{d}{dt} x(t) = \frac{d}{dt} (0.5t^3 - 3.0t^2 + 4.0t) \] \[ v(t) = (0.5 \cdot 3)t^{3-1} - (3.0 \cdot 2)t^{2-1} + (4.0 \cdot 1)t^{1-1} \] \[ \boldsymbol{v(t) = 1.5t^2 - 6.0t + 4.0} \text{ (m/s)} \]

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Average and Instantaneous Acceleration

Good morning/afternoon, everyone. Today, we’re building on our understanding of velocity by introducing acceleration. Acceleration is a concept you encounter daily – speeding up in a car, an elevator starting its ascent. But in physics and engineering, its definition is much more precise and crucial for analyzing dynamic systems, from rockets to microscopic particles. We’ll explore both average and instantaneous acceleration, using our calculus tools.

title: Physics
text:
Average Acceleration
Average acceleration is defined as the rate at which velocity changes.
\[ \bar{a} = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{t_f - t_0} \]

Where:

\(\bar{a}\) is average acceleration.
\(v_f\) is final velocity.
\(v_0\) is initial velocity.
\(\Delta t\) is elapsed time.

SI Units for Acceleration: meters per second squared (m/s\(^2\)).

This means “how many meters per second the velocity changes, each second.”



Recall that velocity is a vector. Therefore, a change in velocity can be a change in magnitude (speed), a change in direction, or both. Acceleration accounts for all these changes.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Acceleration Direction: A Deeper Look
Acceleration is always in the direction of the change in velocity (\(\Delta v\)), not necessarily the direction of motion.



Slowing Down: If an object is moving right (positive velocity) but slowing down, its acceleration is to the left (negative acceleration).

Commonly called “deceleration,” but physically it’s just negative acceleration.
Important: We avoid the term “deceleration” because it’s not a vector and doesn’t specify direction.



 Figure 3.11: An object with initial positive velocity (\(v_0\)) under negative acceleration (\(a\)) comes to rest and reverses direction.







Warning


Key Takeaway: If velocity and acceleration vectors point in opposite directions, the object is slowing down. If they point in the same direction, the object is speeding up.




This is a critical point that often causes confusion. Many students intuitively think acceleration always means speeding up. However, negative acceleration (or acceleration in the opposite direction of motion) means slowing down. This principle is fundamental for understanding braking systems, impact mechanics, and even the dynamics of planetary orbits where acceleration changes direction but not necessarily magnitude.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Visualizing Instantaneous Acceleration

Figure 3.14: In a velocity-time graph, instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent line. Average acceleration approaches this as \(\Delta t \to 0\).

Similar to the position-time graph for velocity, this figure shows that the instantaneous acceleration is the slope of the tangent to the velocity-time curve. Notice that when the velocity curve reaches a maximum or minimum, its slope (and thus the acceleration) is zero. This signifies a momentary change from speeding up to slowing down, or vice-versa.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Engineering Problem: Missile Launch Trajectory
A test missile’s vertical velocity during a critical phase of launch is given by:
\[ v(t) = (15 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \]
where \(v\) is in m/s and \(t\) is in seconds.
Problem:

Find the functional form of the instantaneous acceleration \(a(t)\).
Calculate the instantaneous acceleration at \(t = 10 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 20 \text{ s}\).
Determine the time at which the missile reaches its maximum velocity.
Describe the missile’s motion (speeding up/slowing down and direction) at \(t = 10 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 20 \text{ s}\).


This problem brings together all the concepts we’ve discussed. Analyzing missile trajectories requires exact knowledge of velocity and acceleration at every instant. This is critical for guidance systems, structural integrity, and payload protection. Take some time to apply your knowledge of derivatives and vector interpretation to solve this challenging problem.

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Solution: Missile Launch Trajectory
Let’s solve the missile launch problem.
Given: \(v(t) = 15t - 0.5t^2\) (units omitted for brevity, assuming SI units)
1. Functional form of instantaneous acceleration \(\boldsymbol{a(t)}\): \[ a(t) = \frac{d}{dt} v(t) = \frac{d}{dt} (15t - 0.5t^2) \] \[ a(t) = (15 \cdot 1)t^{1-1} - (0.5 \cdot 2)t^{2-1} \] \[ \boldsymbol{a(t) = 15 - 1.0t} \text{ (m/s}^2\text{)} \]
2. Instantaneous acceleration at \(\boldsymbol{t = 10 \text{ s}}\) and \(\boldsymbol{t = 20 \text{ s}}\):
At \(\boldsymbol{t = 10 \text{ s}}\):
\(a(10) = 15 - 1.0(10) = 15 - 10\)
\(\boldsymbol{a(10 \text{ s}) = 5 \text{ m/s}^2}\)
At \(\boldsymbol{t = 20 \text{ s}}\):
\(a(20) = 15 - 1.0(20) = 15 - 20\)
\(\boldsymbol{a(20 \text{ s}) = -5 \text{ m/s}^2}\)
3. Time at which missile reaches maximum velocity: Maximum velocity occurs when \(a(t) = 0\).
\(15 - 1.0t = 0\)
\(1.0t = 15\)
\(\boldsymbol{t = 15 \text{ s}}\)
4. Describe missile’s motion at \(\boldsymbol{t = 10 \text{ s}}\) and \(\boldsymbol{t = 20 \text{ s}}\):
First, calculate velocities:
\(v(10) = 15(10) - 0.5(10)^2 = 150 - 0.5(100) = 150 - 50 = 100 \text{ m/s}\)
\(v(20) = 15(20) - 0.5(20)^2 = 300 - 0.5(400) = 300 - 200 = 100 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(\boldsymbol{t = 10 \text{ s}}\):

Velocity \(v(10) = +100 \text{ m/s}\) (positive, upward)
Acceleration \(a(10) = +5 \text{ m/s}^2\) (positive, upward)
Interpretation: Since velocity and acceleration are both positive (same direction), the missile is speeding up in the upward direction.

At \(\boldsymbol{t = 20 \text{ s}}\):

Velocity \(v(20) = +100 \text{ m/s}\) (positive, upward)
Acceleration \(a(20) = -5 \text{ m/s}^2\) (negative, downward)
Interpretation: Since velocity is positive and acceleration is negative (opposite directions), the missile is slowing down while still moving upward.


Let’s go through the solution.

Deriving \(a(t)\) from \(v(t)\) is a straightforward application of the power rule.
Plugging in the time values gives us the instantaneous accelerations. Notice the sign change.
The maximum velocity occurs when acceleration is zero. Solving \(a(t)=0\) gives us this critical time.
For the motion description, we need both \(v(t)\) and \(a(t)\) at each point. At \(t=10s\), both are positive, so it’s speeding up. At \(t=20s\), velocity is still positive (moving up), but acceleration is negative (downward), so the missile is slowing down. This kind of analysis is crucial for trajectory correction and engine thrust control in aerospace engineering.

Solution: Autonomous Vehicle Trajectory
2. Determine velocity and speed at \(\boldsymbol{t = 2.0 \text{ s}}\) and \(\boldsymbol{t = 5.0 \text{ s}}\):
At \(\boldsymbol{t = 2.0 \text{ s}}\):
\(v(2.0) = 1.5(2.0)^2 - 6.0(2.0) + 4.0\)
\(v(2.0) = 1.5(4.0) - 12.0 + 4.0 = 6.0 - 12.0 + 4.0\)
\(\boldsymbol{v(2.0 \text{ s}) = -2.0 \text{ m/s}}\)
Speed: \(|v(2.0 \text{ s})| = |-2.0 \text{ m/s}| = \boldsymbol{2.0 \text{ m/s}}\)
At \(\boldsymbol{t = 5.0 \text{ s}}\):
\(v(5.0) = 1.5(5.0)^2 - 6.0(5.0) + 4.0\)
\(v(5.0) = 1.5(25.0) - 30.0 + 4.0 = 37.5 - 30.0 + 4.0\)
\(\boldsymbol{v(5.0 \text{ s}) = 11.5 \text{ m/s}}\)
Speed: \(|v(5.0 \text{ s})| = |11.5 \text{ m/s}| = \boldsymbol{11.5 \text{ m/s}}\)

title: 3 Motion Along a Straight Line
text:
Solution: Autonomous Vehicle Trajectory
3. Find the time(s) when the vehicle is momentarily at rest:
The vehicle is at rest when \(v(t) = 0\).
\(1.5t^2 - 6.0t + 4.0 = 0\)
This is a quadratic equation (\(at^2 + bt + c = 0\)). Use the quadratic formula:
\(t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\)
\(t = \frac{-(-6.0) \pm \sqrt{(-6.0)^2 - 4(1.5)(4.0)}}{2(1.5)}\)
\(t = \frac{6.0 \pm \sqrt{36.0 - 24.0}}{3.0}\)
\(t = \frac{6.0 \pm \sqrt{12.0}}{3.0}\)
\(t_1 = \frac{6.0 + 3.464}{3.0} \approx \boldsymbol{3.15 \text{ s}}\)
\(t_2 = \frac{6.0 - 3.464}{3.0} \approx \boldsymbol{0.85 \text{ s}}\)

Here are the solutions. For part 1, we applied the power rule directly. For part 2, we substituted the time values into our derived velocity function. Note the negative velocity at 2 seconds, indicating movement in the negative direction, but speed is always positive. For part 3, setting \(v(t)=0\) is a critical step to find when an object changes direction or momentarily stops. This required using the quadratic formula, a common mathematical tool in engineering physics. This analysis would be crucial for a control system to anticipate braking or acceleration needs.

section: Engineering Example: Robot on a Production Line (Solution)

Engineering Example: Robot on a Production Line (Solution)
c) Average Velocity (\(\boldsymbol{\bar{v}}\)):
First, calculate total elapsed time: \[ \Delta t_{Total} = \Delta t_1 + \Delta t_2 + \Delta t_3 \] \[ \Delta t_{Total} = 10 \text{ s} + 15 \text{ s} + 5 \text{ s} = 30 \text{ s} \]
Now, use the total displacement and total elapsed time: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x_{Total}}{\Delta t_{Total}} \] \[ \bar{v} = \frac{0 \text{ m}}{30 \text{ s}} \] \[ \boldsymbol{\bar{v} = 0 \text{ m/s}} \]






Tip


Insight: A total displacement of zero means the robot returned to its starting point. This also results in an average velocity of zero, even though it was moving for 30 seconds. This is a common occurrence in cyclic processes in engineering, such as automated assembly lines or reciprocating engine components.




Here’s the step-by-step solution. Notice how we carefully handle the signs for displacement. The key distinction here is that while the robot traveled a significant distance of 16 meters, its final position is the same as its initial position, leading to a zero total displacement and zero average velocity. This is a powerful demonstration of why these terms are distinct and important for engineers, particularly when evaluating system efficiency versus final state.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Describing Motion: Position
To describe an object’s motion, we first define its position (x).



Position: Where an object is located at any particular time.
Frame of Reference: An arbitrary set of axes from which position and motion are described.

Often Earth-based for stationary objects.
Can be moving, e.g., an airplane for a passenger.

For one-dimensional motion, x (or y for vertical) is used.



Figure 3.2: Cyclists’ position can be described relative to buildings or a canal.


Imagine a rocket launch. We describe its position relative to Earth. But for a person inside an airplane, we describe their position relative to the plane itself. The choice of frame of reference is critical for clear analysis.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Introducing Displacement
When an object moves, its position changes. This change is called displacement.



Displacement: The change in position of an object.
It implies movement and indicates both magnitude and direction.
Displacement is a vector quantity.

Can be positive or negative depending on the chosen positive direction.




Figure 3.3: A professor’s displacement from an initial position (\(x_0\)) to a final position (\(x_f\)).


Think of displacement as the straight-line distance and direction from a starting point to an ending point, regardless of the path taken. If you walk 2 meters right, then 4 meters left, your displacement is 2 meters to the left, not 6 meters total.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Displacement: Calculation and Total
Displacement \(\Delta x\) is defined as the change in position:
\[ \Delta x = x_f - x_0 \]

Where:

\(\Delta x\) is displacement.
\(x_f\) is the final position.
\(x_0\) is the initial position.








Tip


The uppercase Greek letter delta (\(\Delta\)) always means “change in” the quantity that follows it.




SI Unit for Displacement: Meter (m).
Total Displacement (\(\Delta x_{Total}\)): The sum of individual displacements. \[ \Delta x_{Total} = \sum \Delta x_i \]


Always remember that displacement is a vector, meaning its sign is crucial. If we define “right” as positive, then moving left means a negative displacement. The SI unit for displacement is meters, and it’s good practice to convert to meters for consistency in calculations.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Average Velocity: The Formula
The average velocity \(\bar{v}\) is defined as the total displacement between two points divided by the elapsed time.
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\text{Displacement between two points}}{\text{Time needed to make the displacement}} \]
Or, more formally:
\[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{x_f - x_0}{t_f - t_0} \]

Where:

\(\bar{v}\) is the average velocity.
\(\Delta x\) is the total displacement.
\(\Delta t\) is the elapsed time (\(t_f - t_0\)).

SI Unit for Average Velocity: Meters per second (m/s).


The units are consistent: meters for displacement, seconds for time, giving meters per second for velocity. This formula is a cornerstone of kinematics, allowing us to quantify how quickly an object is moving in a particular direction over an interval.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Problem: Delivering Flyers
Let’s apply these concepts to a real-world scenario.
Jill’s Trip: Jill sets out from home (x=0).

Leg 1: Travels 0.5 km East in 9 min.
Leg 2: Realizes no more flyers, returns home (0 km) in 9 min.
Leg 3: Gets more flyers, goes 1.0 km East (from home) in 15 min.
Leg 4: Turns West, travels 1.75 km in 25 min, then stops to rest.


This problem describes a multi-segment journey. We’ll need to carefully track Jill’s position and time for each leg to answer the questions. Visualizing this on a number line can be very helpful.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Delivering Flyers: The Questions
Let’s analyze Jill’s journey.

What is Jill’s total displacement to the point where she stops to rest?
What is the magnitude of the final displacement?
What is the average velocity during her entire trip?
What is the total distance traveled?
Make a graph of position versus time.


Figure 3.4: Timeline of Jill’s movements. We define East as the positive direction.

These questions will test our understanding of position, displacement, average velocity, and total distance. Notice that Jill changes direction, which is important for displacement calculations.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Solution Strategy: Jill’s Trip
To tackle this problem effectively, we’ll organize the information.

Assume East is the positive direction.
Jill’s home is the starting point (\(x_0 = 0\)).
Create a table to track time, position, and individual displacements for each leg of the journey.







Tip


Organizing given information into a table is a highly effective problem-solving strategy in physics and engineering.




This systematic approach helps prevent errors and ensures all data points are considered correctly. The table will allow us to easily sum displacements and total time.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Solution: Jill’s Trip - Data Table
Here’s the compiled data for Jill’s trip:








Time \(t_i\) (min)
Position \(x_i\) (km)
Displacement \(\Delta x_i\) (km)




\(t_0 = 0\)
\(x_0 = 0\)
\(\Delta x_0 = 0\)


\(t_1 = 9\)
\(x_1 = 0.5\)
\(\Delta x_1 = x_1 - x_0 = 0.5\)


\(t_2 = 18\)
\(x_2 = 0\)
\(\Delta x_2 = x_2 - x_1 = -0.5\)


\(t_3 = 33\)
\(x_3 = 1.0\)
\(\Delta x_3 = x_3 - x_2 = 1.0\)


\(t_4 = 58\)
\(x_4 = -0.75\)
\(\Delta x_4 = x_4 - x_3 = -1.75\)




Let’s trace these values. Jill starts at 0. At 9 min, she’s at 0.5 km. Then she returns to 0 at 18 min, so her displacement for that leg is -0.5 km. She then goes to 1.0 km from home at 33 min. Finally, she moves 1.75 km west from that 1.0 km mark, placing her at -0.75 km.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Problem-Solving: Jill’s Trip (Q1 & Q2)
1. What is Jill’s total displacement?

Sum of individual displacements: \[ \sum \Delta x_i = 0.5 \text{ km} - 0.5 \text{ km} + 1.0 \text{ km} - 1.75 \text{ km} = -0.75 \text{ km} \]
Answer: Jill’s total displacement is -0.75 km (0.75 km West of home).

2. What is the magnitude of the final displacement?

Magnitude is the absolute value of the total displacement: \[ |-0.75 \text{ km}| = 0.75 \text{ km} \]
Answer: The magnitude of her final displacement is 0.75 km.


The negative sign for total displacement indicates direction: West, since we defined East as positive. The magnitude simply tells us “how far” from the start point, irrespective of direction.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Problem-Solving: Jill’s Trip (Q3 & Q4)
3. What is the average velocity during her entire trip?

Total displacement = -0.75 km
Total elapsed time = 58 min
Convert time to hours or seconds for standard units if needed, but for km/min: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x_{Total}}{\Delta t_{Total}} = \frac{-0.75 \text{ km}}{58 \text{ min}} \approx -0.013 \text{ km/min} \]
Answer: The average velocity is -0.013 km/min (0.013 km/min West).

4. What is the total distance traveled?

Sum of the magnitudes of individual displacements: \[ x_{Total} = |0.5| + |-0.5| + |1.0| + |-1.75| \text{ km} = 0.5 + 0.5 + 1.0 + 1.75 \text{ km} = 3.75 \text{ km} \]
Answer: The total distance traveled is 3.75 km.


Notice the stark difference between displacement (-0.75 km) and total distance traveled (3.75 km). This highlights why both concepts are needed. The average velocity tells us the overall effective “speed” and “direction” if she had traveled in a straight line from start to finish.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Problem-Solving: Jill’s Trip (Q5 - Graph)
5. Make a graph of position versus time.

Figure 3.5: Jill’s position versus time. The average velocity is the slope of a line connecting the initial and final points.

This graph provides a visual representation of Jill’s motion. Each segment’s slope represents her instantaneous velocity during that time. The overall slope from the origin to the final point represents the average velocity. Engineers often use such graphs to analyze and visualize system dynamics.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Significance of Jill’s Trip Results

Total Displacement: -0.75 km.

Means Jill ended up 0.75 km West of her home.

Average Velocity: -0.013 km/min.

If someone walked steadily West at this rate, they’d reach the final point at the same time as Jill.
If Jill ended at home, her total displacement and average velocity would be zero.

Total Distance Traveled: 3.75 km.

This is the actual path length Jill covered.








Important


Displacement and average velocity are path-independent (only depend on start/end points), while total distance traveled is path-dependent.




This summary reinforces the core differences. In engineering, displacement is often critical for structural positioning or robotic navigation, while total distance traveled might be important for fuel consumption or component wear.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Check Your Understanding
Problem: A cyclist rides 3 km west and then turns around and rides 2 km east.

Figure: Cyclist’s movement. Let’s define East as positive.

What is their displacement?
What is the distance traveled?
What is the magnitude of their displacement?


Take a moment to solve this yourself. Think about the definitions of displacement and distance, and remember to assign a positive and negative direction.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Check Your Understanding - Solution (Displacement)
Let’s define East as the positive direction (+) and West as the negative direction (-).
Given: - First leg: 3 km West (\(\Delta x_1 = -3 \text{ km}\)) - Second leg: 2 km East (\(\Delta x_2 = +2 \text{ km}\))
(a) What is their displacement?

Total displacement \(\Delta x_{Total} = \Delta x_1 + \Delta x_2\)
\(\Delta x_{Total} = -3 \text{ km} + 2 \text{ km} = -1 \text{ km}\)

Answer: The cyclist’s displacement is -1 km (or 1 km West).
(c) What is the magnitude of their displacement?

Magnitude of displacement \(= |\Delta x_{Total}|\)
Magnitude \(= |-1 \text{ km}| = 1 \text{ km}\)

Answer: The magnitude of their displacement is 1 km.

The negative sign in the displacement signifies the direction (West). The magnitude tells us simply “how far” the cyclist is from their starting point in a straight line.

title: Linear Algebra
text:
Check Your Understanding - Solution (Distance)
Recall: - First leg: 3 km West - Second leg: 2 km East
(b) What is the distance traveled?

Distance traveled is the sum of the magnitudes of individual paths: \[ x_{Total} = |\Delta x_1| + |\Delta x_2| \]
\(x_{Total} = |{-3 \text{ km}}| + |{+2 \text{ km}}| = 3 \text{ km} + 2 \text{ km} = 5 \text{ km}\)

Answer: The total distance traveled is 5 km.

Notice again the difference: 1 km net displacement vs. 5 km actual distance covered. This problem is a classic way to ensure you understand the core difference between these two fundamental kinematic quantities.

Term
Definition




Position (\(\boldsymbol{x}\))
The location of an object at a particular time relative to a chosen frame of reference.


Frame of Reference
An arbitrary set of axes from which the position and motion of an object are described.


Displacement (\(\Delta x\))
The change in position of an object, indicating both magnitude and direction (a vector). \(\Delta x = x_f - x_0\).


Distance Traveled
The total length of the path an object travels between two positions (a scalar).


Elapsed Time (\(\Delta t\))
The difference between the final time and the initial time.


Average Velocity (\(\bar{v}\))
The displacement divided by the elapsed time; a vector quantity representing the average rate of position change. \(\bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}\).




Mastering these definitions is just as important as knowing the equations. A solid understanding of terminology prevents confusion and ensures accurate problem interpretation.

title: Physics”
section: Beyond Average: The Need for Instantaneous Velocity
text:
Beyond Average: The Need for Instantaneous Velocity
We’ve learned how to calculate average velocity between two points.

However, objects move continuously through space and time.
To fully understand motion, we need to know how fast an object is moving at any single point along its path.
This requires a more precise concept: instantaneous velocity.
To achieve this, we’ll leverage fundamental principles of calculus.


Average velocity gives us an overall picture, but it smooths out all the details. For instance, if you drive 100 miles in 2 hours, your average velocity is 50 mph. But you weren’t driving at exactly 50 mph the entire time; sometimes faster, sometimes slower, perhaps even stopped. Instantaneous velocity captures those precise moments.

title: Physics”
text:
Defining Instantaneous Velocity
The instantaneous velocity is the velocity of an object at a specific instant in time.

It is the average velocity between two points as the time interval (\(\Delta t\)) approaches zero.
Mathematically, if position x is a continuous function of time t, denoted by x(t): \[ \bar{v} = \frac{x(t_2) - x(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1} \]
To find instantaneous velocity, we take the limit as \(\Delta t \to 0\): \[ v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{x(t + \Delta t) - x(t)}{\Delta t} = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]







Important


Instantaneous velocity is the derivative of the position function with respect to time.




This is the fundamental definition. It links the concepts of change in physics with the mathematical power of derivatives. When you see dx/dt, think “the rate of change of position with respect to time.”

title: Physics”
text:
Instantaneous Velocity: Graphical Interpretation

Like average velocity, instantaneous velocity v(t) is a vector quantity (has magnitude and direction).
On a position-versus-time (x(t) vs t) graph, the instantaneous velocity at any point t is the slope of the tangent line at that point.


Figure 3.6: Instantaneous velocity is the slope of the tangent line on an x-t graph.

Look at Figure 3.6. As the time interval Δt gets smaller, the secant line connecting two points on the curve approaches the tangent line at a single point. The slope of this tangent line at time t0 represents the instantaneous velocity at t0. Note that at t0, the slope is zero, meaning the object is momentarily at rest. This point usually corresponds to a maximum or minimum position.

text:
Problem: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
Given the position-versus-time graph in Figure 3.7, find the corresponding velocity-versus-time graph.

Figure 3.7: Position versus time graph.






Tip


Strategy: The velocity during each time interval is the slope of the straight line segment on the position-versus-time graph.




This graph represents piecewise linear motion. For each segment, the slope is constant, meaning the velocity is constant. We simply need to calculate the slope for each interval.

title: Physics”
section: Solution: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
text:
Solution: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
Calculate the slope (velocity) for each interval:

Time interval 0 s to 0.5 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \text{ m} - 0.0 \text{ m}}{0.5 \text{ s} - 0.0 \text{ s}} = 1.0 \text{ m/s} \]
Time interval 0.5 s to 1.0 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \text{ m} - 0.5 \text{ m}}{1.0 \text{ s} - 0.5 \text{ s}} = 0.0 \text{ m/s} \]
Time interval 1.0 s to 2.0 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.0 \text{ m} - 0.5 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} = -0.5 \text{ m/s} \]

The corresponding velocity-versus-time graph is shown in Figure 3.8.

Figure 3.8: Velocity versus time graph.

The significance here is clear: a positive slope on the x-t graph means positive velocity, a zero slope means zero velocity (stopped), and a negative slope means negative velocity (moving in the opposite direction). This graphical analysis is a powerful tool for quickly understanding motion.

section: Speed: A Distinct Concept from Velocity
text:
Speed: A Distinct Concept from Velocity
In physics, speed and velocity are not interchangeable terms.

Speed: Tells us how fast an object is moving.

It is a scalar quantity (magnitude only, no direction).
Always positive or zero.

Average Speed: The total distance traveled divided by the elapsed time. \[ \bar{s} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Elapsed time}} \]







Note


Average speed is not necessarily the magnitude of the average velocity. Example: A round trip where you start and end at the same location has zero average velocity, but non-zero average speed.




This distinction is critical for engineers. When you’re calculating fuel consumption, you care about the total distance traveled (and thus average speed). When you’re designing a navigation system, you care about average velocity because direction matters.

title: Physics”
text:
Instantaneous Speed
While average speed differs from the magnitude of average velocity, instantaneous speed is directly related to instantaneous velocity.

Instantaneous Speed: The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity. \[ \text{Instantaneous speed} = |v(t)| \]

Example: - Particle A: +7.0 m/s (velocity) - Particle B: -7.0 m/s (velocity) - Both have an instantaneous speed of 7.0 m/s.

Table 3.1 (Partial): Speeds of Various Objects.

Instantaneous speed simply quantifies “how fast” without indicating “where to.” It’s the numerical value of the instantaneous velocity, always positive. This table gives you a sense of the vast range of speeds encountered in the physical world.

text:
Calculating Instantaneous Velocity with Calculus
When the position function x(t) is given mathematically, we use differentiation to find v(t).

For polynomial position functions, x(t) often consists of terms in the form of At^n.
We use the power rule of differentiation: \[ \frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = An \cdot t^{n-1} \]
If x(t) has multiple terms added or subtracted, differentiate each term separately and sum the results.


The power rule is a cornerstone of calculus in physics. Make sure you’re comfortable with it. A is a constant coefficient, n is an integer power. Remember that the derivative of a constant term is zero, and the derivative of At (where n=1) is simply A.

title: Physics”
text:
Problem: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Example 3.3)
The position of a particle is given by: \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \]

Find the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\).
Calculate the average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\).


This problem directly tests your ability to apply the calculus rules for instantaneous velocity and the algebraic definition for average velocity. Pay attention to units!

title: Physics”
text:
Solution: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Part 1)
1. Instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\):

First, find the general instantaneous velocity function v(t) by differentiating x(t): \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \] \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (3.0 \text{ m/s})t \right] + \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \right] \] Applying the power rule: \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) \cdot 1 \cdot t^{1-1} + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3) \cdot 3 \cdot t^{3-1} \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \]
Now, substitute \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\): \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(2.0 \text{ s})^2 \] \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(4.0 \text{ s}^2) \] \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} + 6.0 \text{ m/s} = 9.0 \text{ m/s} \]

Answer: The instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\) is \(9.0 \text{ m/s}\).

Make sure you understand each step of the differentiation. The units are important for verification; notice how s^2 in the denominator of the coefficient 1.5 m/s^3 cancels with s^2 from t^2 to yield m/s.

title: Physics”
text:
Solution: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Part 2)
2. Average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\):

First, find the position at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\) using \(x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3\): \[ x(1.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(1.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(1.0 \text{ s})^3 = 3.0 \text{ m} + 0.5 \text{ m} = 3.5 \text{ m} \] \[ x(3.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(3.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(3.0 \text{ s})^3 = 9.0 \text{ m} + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(27.0 \text{ s}^3) = 9.0 \text{ m} + 13.5 \text{ m} = 22.5 \text{ m} \]
Now, calculate the average velocity: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{x(3.0 \text{ s}) - x(1.0 \text{ s})}{3.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} = \frac{22.5 \text{ m} - 3.5 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = \frac{19.0 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = 9.5 \text{ m/s} \]

Answer: The average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\) is \(9.5 \text{ m/s}\).

Notice that the instantaneous velocity at 2.0 s (9.0 m/s) is close to the average velocity over the interval from 1.0 s to 3.0 s (9.5 m/s). As the time interval for average velocity shrinks and centers around 2.0 s, the average velocity would converge to the instantaneous velocity at 2.0 s.

title: Physics”
text:
Problem: Instantaneous Velocity Versus Speed (Example 3.4)
Consider the motion of a particle with position: \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \]

What is the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\), \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\), and \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)?
What is the speed of the particle at these times?


This problem highlights how velocity can change direction, and how speed is always positive. We’ll use differentiation to find velocity, then take its magnitude for speed.

title: Physics”
text:
Solution: Instantaneous Velocity Versus Speed
1. Instantaneous velocity:

First, find the general instantaneous velocity function v(t): \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (3.0 \text{ m/s})t - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \right] \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2) \cdot 2 \cdot t^{2-1} \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t \]
Now, substitute the given times:

At \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\): \(v(0.25 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(0.25 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 1.5 \text{ m/s} = 1.5 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\): \(v(0.50 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(0.50 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 3.0 \text{ m/s} = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\): \(v(1.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(1.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 6.0 \text{ m/s} = -3.0 \text{ m/s}\)


2. Speed of the particle:

Speed is the magnitude of velocity, \(|v(t)|\):

At \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |1.5 \text{ m/s}| = 1.5 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |0 \text{ m/s}| = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |-3.0 \text{ m/s}| = 3.0 \text{ m/s}\)



Observe the velocity at 0.50 s. It’s zero. This means the particle momentarily stops and reverses direction. At 1.0 s, the velocity is negative, indicating movement in the negative direction, but the speed is positive, just showing ‘how fast’.

Check Your Understanding 3.2
The position of an object as a function of time is given by: \[ x(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \]

What is the velocity of the object as a function of time?
Is the velocity ever positive?
What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)?


Pause here and try to solve this on your own. Remember the power rule for differentiation, and the definition of speed.

title: Physics”
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.2 - Solution
Given position function: \(x(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2\)
(a) What is the velocity of the object as a function of time? - Differentiate \(x(t)\) with respect to \(t\): \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \right] \] \[ v(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2) \cdot 2 \cdot t^{2-1} \] \[ v(t) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t \]
Answer (a): The velocity of the object as a function of time is \(v(t) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t\).
(b) Is the velocity ever positive? - Since \(t\) (time) is always \(\ge 0\), and the coefficient \((-6 \text{ m/s}^2)\) is negative, the product \((-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t\) will always be \(\le 0\).
Answer (b): No, the velocity is never positive. It is either zero (at \(t=0\)) or negative.
(c) What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)? - At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\): \(v(1.0 \text{ s}) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)(1.0 \text{ s}) = -6.0 \text{ m/s}\) - Speed is the magnitude of velocity: Speed \(= |v(1.0 \text{ s})| = |-6.0 \text{ m/s}| = 6.0 \text{ m/s}\)
Answer (c): At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\), the velocity is \(-6.0 \text{ m/s}\) and the speed is \(6.0 \text{ m/s}\).

This problem reinforces the definitions. The object starts at rest at the origin and then continuously moves in the negative direction, with its speed increasing linearly.

title: Physics
text:
Key Terms







Term
Definition




Acceleration
The rate of change of velocity; a vector quantity with units of m/s\(^2\).


Average Acceleration
The change in velocity divided by the elapsed time; \(\bar{a} = \Delta v / \Delta t\).


Instantaneous Acceleration
The acceleration of an object at a specific point in time; the derivative of the velocity function with respect to time (\(a(t) = dv(t)/dt\)).


Second Derivative
The derivative of a derivative; related to instantaneous acceleration (\(a(t) = d^2x(t)/dt^2\)).




Understanding these terms is fundamental to describing and predicting the motion of objects in engineering physics.

title: Physics
text:
Understanding Acceleration

In everyday terms, accelerate means to speed up; applying brakes means to slow down.
In physics, acceleration is more inclusive: it’s about the change in velocity over time.
A greater acceleration implies a greater change in velocity over a given time.
Examples:

Car acceleration/braking.
Subatomic particles in accelerators.
Cosmic rays accelerated by supernovas.



Acceleration is not just about speeding up. It’s about any change in velocity, which, as we’ll see, includes changes in direction even if speed remains constant. This broad definition is crucial in physics and engineering.

title: Physics
text:
Acceleration and Direction of Motion

Acceleration is not always in the direction of motion.
When an object slows down, its acceleration is opposite to the direction of its motion.


Figure 3.11: An object with positive velocity and negative acceleration will eventually stop and reverse direction.

This figure illustrates a common scenario. If an object moving East (positive velocity) experiences a constant acceleration West (negative acceleration), it will slow down, momentarily stop, and then reverse direction, moving West with increasing speed. This phenomenon is critical in understanding projectile motion or braking systems.

text:
Problem: Calculating Average Acceleration
A racehorse coming out of the gate accelerates from rest to a velocity of \(15.0 \text{ m/s}\) due west in \(1.80 \text{ s}\).
What is its average acceleration?

Figure 3.12: Racehorses accelerating out of the gate.

This is a straightforward application of the average acceleration formula. Remember to assign a coordinate system and be consistent with signs.

title: Physics
text:
Strategy: Racehorse Acceleration

Draw a sketch and assign a coordinate system.

Let’s define East as positive (+) and West as negative (-).
This means a velocity of 15.0 m/s due West is \(v_f = -15.0 \text{ m/s}\).



Figure 3.13: Coordinate system for the racehorse problem.

Identify knowns:

Initial velocity (\(v_0\)): From rest, so \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\).
Final velocity (\(v_f\)): \(15.0 \text{ m/s}\) due West, so \(v_f = -15.0 \text{ m/s}\).
Time interval (\(\Delta t\)): \(1.80 \text{ s}\).

Use the average acceleration formula: \(\bar{a} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{\Delta t}\).


Setting up the problem correctly with a clear coordinate system is half the battle. The negative sign for velocity due to “West” is a critical detail.

Check Your Understanding 3.3
Problem: Protons in a linear accelerator are accelerated from rest to \(2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}\) in \(10^{-4} \text{ s}\).
What is the average acceleration of the protons?

Apply the same principles as the previous example. Identify the initial velocity, final velocity, and time interval.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.3 - Solution
Given: - Initial velocity (\(v_0\)): From rest, so \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\). - Final velocity (\(v_f\)): \(2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}\). - Time interval (\(\Delta t\)): \(10^{-4} \text{ s}\).
Calculation of average acceleration (\(\bar{a}\)): \[ \bar{a} = \frac{v_f - v_0}{\Delta t} \] \[ \bar{a} = \frac{(2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}) - 0 \text{ m/s}}{10^{-4} \text{ s}} \] \[ \bar{a} = \frac{2.0 \times 10^7 \text{ m/s}}{10^{-4} \text{ s}} = 2.0 \times 10^{11} \text{ m/s}^2 \]
Answer: The average acceleration of the protons is \(2.0 \times 10^{11} \text{ m/s}^2\).

This is an incredibly large acceleration, typical for subatomic particles in particle accelerators, showcasing the extreme scales encountered in physics. The direction of acceleration would be in the direction of the final velocity, as they started from rest and sped up.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating Instantaneous Acceleration (Example 3.6)
A particle’s velocity is given by: \[ v(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \]

Find the functional form of the acceleration.
Find the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\).
Find the instantaneous acceleration at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\).
Interpret the results of (c) in terms of the directions of the acceleration and velocity vectors.


This problem requires applying differentiation twice: once for velocity from position (implicitly, if needed), and once for acceleration from velocity. Then, interpreting the signs of velocity and acceleration together.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Instantaneous Acceleration (Part 1 & 2)
1. Functional form of acceleration: - Differentiate \(v(t)\) with respect to \(t\): \[ a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \right] \] \[ a(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2) \cdot 1 \cdot t^{1-1} - (5 \text{ m/s}^3) \cdot 2 \cdot t^{2-1} \] \[ a(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2) - (10 \text{ m/s}^3)t \]
Answer (1): \(a(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2) - (10 \text{ m/s}^3)t\).
2. Instantaneous velocity at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\): - Using \(v(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2\): - \(v(1 \text{ s}) = 20(1) - 5(1)^2 = 15 \text{ m/s}\) - \(v(2 \text{ s}) = 20(2) - 5(2)^2 = 40 - 20 = 20 \text{ m/s}\) - \(v(3 \text{ s}) = 20(3) - 5(3)^2 = 60 - 45 = 15 \text{ m/s}\) - \(v(5 \text{ s}) = 20(5) - 5(5)^2 = 100 - 125 = -25 \text{ m/s}\)
Answer (2): \(v(1 \text{ s}) = 15 \text{ m/s}\), \(v(2 \text{ s}) = 20 \text{ m/s}\), \(v(3 \text{ s}) = 15 \text{ m/s}\), \(v(5 \text{ s}) = -25 \text{ m/s}\).

Pay attention to the units throughout the calculation. For velocity, at each time point, the calculation leads to units of m/s. The coefficients in the v(t) function are not dimensionless.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Instantaneous Acceleration (Part 3 & 4)
3. Instantaneous acceleration at \(t = 1, 2, 3, \text{ and } 5 \text{ s}\): - Using \(a(t) = (20 \text{ m/s}^2) - (10 \text{ m/s}^3)t\): - \(a(1 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(1) = 10 \text{ m/s}^2\) - \(a(2 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(2) = 0 \text{ m/s}^2\) - \(a(3 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(3) = -10 \text{ m/s}^2\) - \(a(5 \text{ s}) = 20 - 10(5) = -30 \text{ m/s}^2\)
Answer (3): \(a(1 \text{ s}) = 10 \text{ m/s}^2\), \(a(2 \text{ s}) = 0 \text{ m/s}^2\), \(a(3 \text{ s}) = -10 \text{ m/s}^2\), \(a(5 \text{ s}) = -30 \text{ m/s}^2\).
4. Interpretation of results:

At \(t = 1 \text{ s}\): \(v = 15 \text{ m/s}\) (positive), \(a = 10 \text{ m/s}^2\) (positive). Velocity and acceleration are in the same direction. Particle is speeding up.
At \(t = 2 \text{ s}\): \(v = 20 \text{ m/s}\) (positive), \(a = 0 \text{ m/s}^2\). Velocity is momentarily at its maximum; acceleration is zero.
At \(t = 3 \text{ s}\): \(v = 15 \text{ m/s}\) (positive), \(a = -10 \text{ m/s}^2\) (negative). Velocity and acceleration are in opposite directions. Particle is slowing down.
At \(t = 5 \text{ s}\): \(v = -25 \text{ m/s}\) (negative), \(a = -30 \text{ m/s}^2\) (negative). Velocity and acceleration are in the same direction (both negative). Particle has reversed direction and is speeding up in the negative direction.


The interpretation of the signs of velocity and acceleration is paramount. If they have the same sign, the object is speeding up. If they have opposite signs, the object is slowing down. When acceleration is zero, velocity is at an extremum (max or min).
