Figure 3.16 (a): Velocity versus time. Tangent lines illustrate acceleration.


Figure 3.16 (b): Acceleration versus time.

Significance: - When a(t) is positive and v(t) is positive (e.g., at t=1s), the object speeds up. - When a(t) is zero (at t=2s), v(t) is at its maximum. - When a(t) is negative but v(t) is still positive (e.g., at t=3s), the object slows down. - When a(t) is negative and v(t) becomes negative (e.g., at t=5s), the object speeds up in the negative direction.

These graphs neatly summarize the dynamic interplay between velocity and acceleration. Engineers often use such graphs to analyze and predict the behavior of systems.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.4
Problem: An airplane lands on a runway traveling east. Describe its acceleration.

Think about what happens to the airplane’s velocity as it lands. Which direction is its initial velocity, and how does that velocity change?

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.4 - Solution
Answer:

Direction of Motion: The airplane is traveling East. Let’s designate East as the positive (+) direction. Therefore, its initial velocity is positive.
Change in Velocity: When an airplane lands, it is slowing down. Its speed decreases, eventually reaching zero.
Direction of Acceleration: For the airplane to slow down while moving East (positive velocity), its acceleration must be in the opposite direction of its motion.

Therefore, the airplane’s acceleration is West (negative direction).

Even though the plane is “decelerating,” we explicitly state its acceleration is in the negative direction (West) because that is the direction of the change in velocity.

title: Physics
text:
Getting a Feel for Acceleration

Accelerations vary widely, from continental drift (\(10^{-7} \text{ m/s}^2\)) to proton acceleration in a collider (\(1.9 \times 10^9 \text{ m/s}^2\)).
Acceleration magnitude is independent of object size or mass (in kinematics).
Average acceleration can be very different from instantaneous acceleration, especially when motion is not smooth.


Figure 3.17: Comparing average and instantaneous acceleration for different motions.

Table 3.2 illustrates the vast range of accelerations in the universe. Figure 3.17 (b) vividly demonstrates how instantaneous acceleration can fluctuate rapidly, making average acceleration less representative for complex movements. This highlights why instantaneous analysis is crucial for precise engineering.

title: Physics
section: Beyond Average: The Need for Instantaneous Velocity
text:
Beyond Average: The Need for Instantaneous Velocity
We’ve learned how to calculate average velocity between two points.

However, objects move continuously through space and time.
To fully understand motion, we need to know how fast an object is moving at any single point along its path.
This requires a more precise concept: instantaneous velocity.
To achieve this, we’ll leverage fundamental principles of calculus.


Average velocity gives us an overall picture, but it smooths out all the details. For instance, if you drive 100 miles in 2 hours, your average velocity is 50 mph. But you weren’t driving at exactly 50 mph the entire time; sometimes faster, sometimes slower, perhaps even stopped. Instantaneous velocity captures those precise moments.

title: Physics
text:
Defining Instantaneous Velocity
The instantaneous velocity is the velocity of an object at a specific instant in time.

It is the average velocity between two points as the time interval (\(\Delta t\)) approaches zero.
Mathematically, if position x is a continuous function of time t, denoted by x(t): \[ \bar{v} = \frac{x(t_2) - x(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1} \]
To find instantaneous velocity, we take the limit as \(\Delta t \to 0\): \[ v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{x(t + \Delta t) - x(t)}{\Delta t} = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]







Important


Instantaneous velocity is the derivative of the position function with respect to time.




This is the fundamental definition. It links the concepts of change in physics with the mathematical power of derivatives. When you see dx/dt, think “the rate of change of position with respect to time.”

title: Physics
section: Problem: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
text:
Problem: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
Given the position-versus-time graph in Figure 3.7, find the corresponding velocity-versus-time graph.

Figure 3.7: Position versus time graph.






Tip


Strategy: The velocity during each time interval is the slope of the straight line segment on the position-versus-time graph.




This graph represents piecewise linear motion. For each segment, the slope is constant, meaning the velocity is constant. We simply need to calculate the slope for each interval.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
text:
Solution: Finding Velocity from a Position-Versus-Time Graph
Calculate the slope (velocity) for each interval:

Time interval 0 s to 0.5 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \text{ m} - 0.0 \text{ m}}{0.5 \text{ s} - 0.0 \text{ s}} = 1.0 \text{ m/s} \]
Time interval 0.5 s to 1.0 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.5 \text{ m} - 0.5 \text{ m}}{1.0 \text{ s} - 0.5 \text{ s}} = 0.0 \text{ m/s} \]
Time interval 1.0 s to 2.0 s: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{0.0 \text{ m} - 0.5 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} = -0.5 \text{ m/s} \]

The corresponding velocity-versus-time graph is shown in Figure 3.8.

Figure 3.8: Velocity versus time graph.

The significance here is clear: a positive slope on the x-t graph means positive velocity, a zero slope means zero velocity (stopped), and a negative slope means negative velocity (moving in the opposite direction). This graphical analysis is a powerful tool for quickly understanding motion.

title: Physics
section: Speed: A Distinct Concept from Velocity
text:
Speed: A Distinct Concept from Velocity
In physics, speed and velocity are not interchangeable terms.

Speed: Tells us how fast an object is moving.

It is a scalar quantity (magnitude only, no direction).
Always positive or zero.

Average Speed: The total distance traveled divided by the elapsed time. \[ \bar{s} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Elapsed time}} \]







Note


Average speed is not necessarily the magnitude of the average velocity. Example: A round trip where you start and end at the same location has zero average velocity, but non-zero average speed.




This distinction is critical for engineers. When you’re calculating fuel consumption, you care about the total distance traveled (and thus average speed). When you’re designing a navigation system, you care about average velocity because direction matters.

title: Physics
text:
Instantaneous Speed
While average speed differs from the magnitude of average velocity, instantaneous speed is directly related to instantaneous velocity.

Instantaneous Speed: The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity. \[ \text{Instantaneous speed} = |v(t)| \]

Example: - Particle A: +7.0 m/s (velocity) - Particle B: -7.0 m/s (velocity) - Both have an instantaneous speed of 7.0 m/s.

Table 3.1 (Partial): Speeds of Various Objects.

Instantaneous speed simply quantifies “how fast” without indicating “where to.” It’s the numerical value of the instantaneous velocity, always positive. This table gives you a sense of the vast range of speeds encountered in the physical world.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Example 3.3)
The position of a particle is given by: \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \]

Find the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\).
Calculate the average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\).


This problem directly tests your ability to apply the calculus rules for instantaneous velocity and the algebraic definition for average velocity. Pay attention to units!

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Part 1)
1. Instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\):

First, find the general instantaneous velocity function v(t) by differentiating x(t): \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \] \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (3.0 \text{ m/s})t \right] + \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3 \right] \] Applying the power rule: \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) \cdot 1 \cdot t^{1-1} + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3) \cdot 3 \cdot t^{3-1} \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^2 \]
Now, substitute \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\): \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(2.0 \text{ s})^2 \] \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) + (1.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(4.0 \text{ s}^2) \] \[ v(2.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} + 6.0 \text{ m/s} = 9.0 \text{ m/s} \]

Answer: The instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0 \text{ s}\) is \(9.0 \text{ m/s}\).

Make sure you understand each step of the differentiation. The units are important for verification; notice how s^2 in the denominator of the coefficient 1.5 m/s^3 cancels with s^2 from t^2 to yield m/s.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Instantaneous vs. Average Velocity (Part 2)
2. Average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\):

First, find the position at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\) using \(x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)t^3\): \[ x(1.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(1.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(1.0 \text{ s})^3 = 3.0 \text{ m} + 0.5 \text{ m} = 3.5 \text{ m} \] \[ x(3.0 \text{ s}) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})(3.0 \text{ s}) + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(3.0 \text{ s})^3 = 9.0 \text{ m} + (0.5 \text{ m/s}^3)(27.0 \text{ s}^3) = 9.0 \text{ m} + 13.5 \text{ m} = 22.5 \text{ m} \]
Now, calculate the average velocity: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{x(3.0 \text{ s}) - x(1.0 \text{ s})}{3.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} = \frac{22.5 \text{ m} - 3.5 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = \frac{19.0 \text{ m}}{2.0 \text{ s}} = 9.5 \text{ m/s} \]

Answer: The average velocity between \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\) and \(t = 3.0 \text{ s}\) is \(9.5 \text{ m/s}\).

Notice that the instantaneous velocity at 2.0 s (9.0 m/s) is close to the average velocity over the interval from 1.0 s to 3.0 s (9.5 m/s). As the time interval for average velocity shrinks and centers around 2.0 s, the average velocity would converge to the instantaneous velocity at 2.0 s.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Instantaneous Velocity Versus Speed (Example 3.4)
Consider the motion of a particle with position: \[ x(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s})t - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \]

What is the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\), \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\), and \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)?
What is the speed of the particle at these times?


This problem highlights how velocity can change direction, and how speed is always positive. We’ll use differentiation to find velocity, then take its magnitude for speed.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Instantaneous Velocity Versus Speed
1. Instantaneous velocity:

First, find the general instantaneous velocity function v(t): \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (3.0 \text{ m/s})t - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \right] \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) - (3.0 \text{ m/s}^2) \cdot 2 \cdot t^{2-1} \] \[ v(t) = (3.0 \text{ m/s}) - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)t \]
Now, substitute the given times:

At \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\): \(v(0.25 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(0.25 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 1.5 \text{ m/s} = 1.5 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\): \(v(0.50 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(0.50 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 3.0 \text{ m/s} = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\): \(v(1.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - (6.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(1.0 \text{ s}) = 3.0 \text{ m/s} - 6.0 \text{ m/s} = -3.0 \text{ m/s}\)


2. Speed of the particle:

Speed is the magnitude of velocity, \(|v(t)|\):

At \(t = 0.25 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |1.5 \text{ m/s}| = 1.5 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 0.50 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |0 \text{ m/s}| = 0 \text{ m/s}\)
At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\): Speed \(= |-3.0 \text{ m/s}| = 3.0 \text{ m/s}\)



Observe the velocity at 0.50 s. It’s zero. This means the particle momentarily stops and reverses direction. At 1.0 s, the velocity is negative, indicating movement in the negative direction, but the speed is positive, just showing ‘how fast’.

title: Physics
text:
Visualizing Velocity and Speed
These graphs from Example 3.4 illustrate the concepts visually.


 Figure 3.9 (a): Position: x(t) vs time.

 Figure 3.9 (b): Velocity: v(t) vs time.

 Figure 3.9 (c): Speed: |v(t)| vs time.



The x(t) graph shows the particle moving in the positive direction, stopping at 0.5 s (where the slope is zero), and then moving in the negative direction.
The v(t) graph shows the velocity linearly decreasing, crossing zero at 0.5 s, and then becoming negative. This visually confirms the calculations.
The |v(t)| graph shows the speed. It’s always positive, reflecting the magnitude of velocity. It decreases to zero when the object stops and then increases as it moves in the negative direction.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.2
The position of an object as a function of time is given by: \[ x(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \]

What is the velocity of the object as a function of time?
Is the velocity ever positive?
What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)?


Pause here and try to solve this on your own. Remember the power rule for differentiation, and the definition of speed.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.2 - Solution
Given position function: \(x(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2\)
(a) What is the velocity of the object as a function of time?

Differentiate \(x(t)\) with respect to \(t\):
\[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt} \left[ (-3 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \right] \]
\[ v(t) = (-3 \text{ m/s}^2) \cdot 2 \cdot t^{2-1} \]
\[ v(t) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t \]

Answer (a): The velocity of the object as a function of time is \(v(t) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t\).
(b) Is the velocity ever positive?

Since \(t\) (time) is always \(\ge 0\), and the coefficient \((-6 \text{ m/s}^2)\) is negative, the product \((-6 \text{ m/s}^2)t\) will always be \(\le 0\).

Answer (b): No, the velocity is never positive. It is either zero (at \(t=0\)) or negative.
(c) What are the velocity and speed at \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\)?

At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\):
\(v(1.0 \text{ s}) = (-6 \text{ m/s}^2)(1.0 \text{ s}) = -6.0 \text{ m/s}\)
Speed is the magnitude of velocity:
Speed \(= |v(1.0 \text{ s})| = |-6.0 \text{ m/s}| = 6.0 \text{ m/s}\)

Answer (c): At \(t = 1.0 \text{ s}\), the velocity is \(-6.0 \text{ m/s}\) and the speed is \(6.0 \text{ m/s}\).

This problem reinforces the definitions. The object starts at rest at the origin and then continuously moves in the negative direction, with its speed increasing linearly.

title: Physics
text:
Key Equations
Here are the essential equations introduced in this section:







Equation
Description




\(v(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} = \frac{dx(t)}{dt}\)
Defines instantaneous velocity as the derivative of position


\(\frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = An \cdot t^{n-1}\)
Power rule for differentiating polynomial terms


\(\bar{s} = \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Elapsed time}}\)
Defines average speed


Instantaneous speed \(= |v(t)|\)
Relates instantaneous speed to instantaneous velocity




These formulas are your primary tools for solving problems involving instantaneous velocity and speed. Practice applying the power rule of differentiation.

title: Physics
text:
Key Terms







Term
Definition




Instantaneous Velocity
The velocity of an object at a specific point in time; the limit of the average velocity as the elapsed time approaches zero.


Instantaneous Speed
The magnitude of the instantaneous velocity; a scalar quantity that indicates how fast an object is moving.


Average Speed
The total distance traveled divided by the elapsed time; a scalar quantity.


Derivative
A mathematical tool used to find the rate at which a function’s value changes at a specific point.


Power Rule (Calculus)
A rule for differentiating terms of the form \(At^n\), stating \(\frac{d(At^n)}{dt} = An \cdot t^{n-1}\).




A solid grasp of these terms is fundamental to understanding kinematics and dynamics. Pay close attention to whether a concept is a vector or a scalar.

title: Physics
text:
The Importance of Constant Acceleration

We intuitively know that greater acceleration leads to greater displacement.
This section develops specific equations relating displacement, velocity, and acceleration under the assumption of constant acceleration.
This assumption is:

True for many real-world situations (e.g., free fall, many controlled systems).
A good approximation for average behavior in complex motions.
Allows complex motions to be broken into segments with constant acceleration.



While real-world acceleration might vary, constant acceleration provides a robust framework. Think of a car accelerating uniformly, or a ball falling near Earth’s surface. Even complex motions can often be modeled as a series of constant acceleration phases.

title: Physics
text:
Simplifying Notation
To make our equations cleaner, we’ll adopt a simplified notation:

Initial time (\(t_0\)): Set to zero (like starting a stopwatch).
Elapsed time (\(\Delta t\)): Becomes simply t (final time).
Initial values: Denoted with subscript 0 (e.g., \(x_0\), \(v_0\)).
Final values: Have no subscript (e.g., \(x\), \(v\)).



Standard Notation

\(\Delta t = t_f - t_0\)
\(\Delta x = x_f - x_0\)
\(\Delta v = v_f - v_0\)


Simplified Notation (for \(t_0 = 0\))

\(\Delta t = t\)
\(\Delta x = x - x_0\)
\(\Delta v = v - v_0\)








Note


A key assumption: acceleration (\(\boldsymbol{a}\)) is constant. Therefore, average acceleration (\(\bar{a}\)) equals instantaneous acceleration (\(a\)).




This simplification is standard in kinematics for constant acceleration problems. It streamlines our equations and reduces clutter. The constant acceleration assumption is critical; it means we don’t need calculus to find instantaneous acceleration.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 1: Displacement from Average Velocity
text:
Kinematic Equation 1: Displacement from Average Velocity
We start with the definition of average velocity: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation (\(t_0=0\), \(\Delta t=t\), \(\Delta x = x - x_0\)): \[ \bar{v} = \frac{x - x_0}{t} \]
Solving for final position \(x\): \[ x = x_0 + \bar{v}t \]
When acceleration is constant, the average velocity is the simple average of the initial and final velocities: \[ \bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \]






Tip


This formula for \(\bar{v}\) is only valid when acceleration is constant.




This first equation relates position, initial position, average velocity, and time. The special case of constant acceleration allows us to express average velocity in a very convenient form, which we will use for further derivations.

title: Physics
section: Graphical Insight: Average Velocity with Constant Acceleration
text:
Graphical Insight: Average Velocity with Constant Acceleration

Figure 3.18 (a): Constant acceleration. The average velocity is exactly halfway between \(v_0\) and \(v\).

When acceleration is constant, velocity changes linearly.
The average velocity over an interval is simply the arithmetic mean of the initial and final velocities. \[ \bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \] (For example, \((40 + 80) / 2 = 60 \text{ km/h}\))


This graph visually confirms why the simple average formula for velocity works. With a straight line (constant acceleration) on a velocity-time graph, the area under the curve (displacement) can be found using the average height of the trapezoid, which is exactly the average velocity.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equation 2: Final Velocity
We start with the definition of (constant) acceleration: \[ a = \frac{\Delta v}{\Delta t} \]
Using simplified notation (\(t_0=0\), \(\Delta t=t\), \(\Delta v = v - v_0\)): \[ a = \frac{v - v_0}{t} \]
Solving for final velocity \(v\): \[ v = v_0 + at \quad \text{(constant } a \text{)} \]






Important


This equation relates final velocity, initial velocity, constant acceleration, and time.




This is a very powerful equation. It tells us that the final velocity depends on the initial velocity and how much the acceleration “acts” over time.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating Final Velocity (Airplane)
An airplane lands with an initial velocity of \(70.0 \text{ m/s}\) and then accelerates opposite to the motion at \(1.50 \text{ m/s}^2\) for \(40.0 \text{ s}\).
What is its final velocity?

This problem asks for final velocity and provides initial velocity, acceleration, and time. Choose the appropriate kinematic equation. Remember to define a positive direction!

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Final Velocity (Airplane)
Strategy:

Define coordinate system: Let the initial direction of motion (East) be positive (+).
Identify knowns:

Initial velocity (\(v_0 = +70.0 \text{ m/s}\))
Acceleration (\(a = -1.50 \text{ m/s}^2\), since it’s opposite to motion)
Time (\(t = 40.0 \text{ s}\))

Identify unknown: Final velocity (\(v\)).
Choose equation: \(v = v_0 + at\).


Figure 3.19: Airplane slowing down.
Solution: \[ v = 70.0 \text{ m/s} + (-1.50 \text{ m/s}^2)(40.0 \text{ s}) \] \[ v = 70.0 \text{ m/s} - 60.0 \text{ m/s} = 10.0 \text{ m/s} \]
Answer: The airplane’s final velocity is \(10.0 \text{ m/s}\).

The final velocity is positive, meaning the plane is still moving in the original direction (East), but much slower. This calculation is vital for runway length requirements or braking system design.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equation 3: Final Position
We combine \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\) and \(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\). Substituting \(\bar{v}\): \[ x = x_0 + \left( \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \right)t \]
Then substitute \(v = v_0 + at\): \[ x = x_0 + \left( \frac{v_0 + (v_0 + at)}{2} \right)t \] \[ x = x_0 + \left( \frac{2v_0 + at}{2} \right)t \] \[ x = x_0 + \left( v_0 + \frac{1}{2}at \right)t \] \[ x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \quad \text{(constant } a \text{)} \]






Important


This equation relates final position, initial position, initial velocity, constant acceleration, and time.




This equation is particularly useful when you don’t know the final velocity but know the acceleration and time. It shows how displacement grows quadratically with time when acceleration is present.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating Displacement (Dragster)
A dragster accelerates from rest at \(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\) for \(5.56 \text{ s}\).
How far does it travel in this time?

Figure 3.20: Dragster at start.

Here, we need to find displacement. We’re given initial velocity (from rest), acceleration, and time. Which equation fits best?

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Displacement (Dragster)
Strategy:

Define coordinate system: Let the starting line be \(x_0 = 0\).
Identify knowns:

Initial position (\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\))
Initial velocity (\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\), from rest)
Acceleration (\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\))
Time (\(t = 5.56 \text{ s}\))

Identify unknown: Final position (\(x\)).
Choose equation: \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\).


Figure 3.21: Sketch of an accelerating dragster.
Solution: Since \(x_0 = 0\) and \(v_0 = 0\): \[ x = 0 + (0)t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \] \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(5.56 \text{ s})^2 \] \[ x = \frac{1}{2}(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(30.9136 \text{ s}^2) \approx 401.87 \text{ m} \]
Answer: The dragster travels approximately \(402 \text{ m}\).

This distance is very close to a quarter-mile, the standard for drag racing. This equation shows how quickly distance can accumulate even from rest with high acceleration.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equation 4: Final Velocity from Displacement
text:
Kinematic Equation 4: Final Velocity from Displacement
We can derive a fourth useful equation by combining \(v = v_0 + at\) and \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\) (where \(\bar{v} = (v_0 + v)/2\)).

From \(v = v_0 + at\), solve for \(t\): \[ t = \frac{v - v_0}{a} \]
Substitute this expression for \(t\) and \(\bar{v} = (v_0 + v)/2\) into \(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\): \[ x = x_0 + \left( \frac{v_0 + v}{2} \right) \left( \frac{v - v_0}{a} \right) \] \[ x - x_0 = \frac{v^2 - v_0^2}{2a} \]

Solving for \(v^2\): \[ v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0) \quad \text{(constant } a \text{)} \]






Important


This equation relates final velocity, initial velocity, constant acceleration, and displacement. Time is not directly included.




This equation is extremely useful when time is not known or not relevant to the problem. It highlights the direct relationship between velocity change and displacement under constant acceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating Final Velocity (without time)
Calculate the final velocity of the dragster from the previous problem (accelerates from rest at \(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\), travels \(402 \text{ m}\)) without using information about time.

We have initial velocity, acceleration, and displacement. We need final velocity. This is a perfect scenario for the fourth kinematic equation.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Final Velocity (without time)
Strategy:

Identify knowns:

Initial velocity (\(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\))
Acceleration (\(a = 26.0 \text{ m/s}^2\))
Displacement (\(x - x_0 = 402 \text{ m}\))

Identify unknown: Final velocity (\(v\)).
Choose equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\).

Solution: \[ v^2 = (0 \text{ m/s})^2 + 2(26.0 \text{ m/s}^2)(402 \text{ m}) \] \[ v^2 = 0 + 20904 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \] \[ v = \sqrt{20904 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2} \approx 144.58 \text{ m/s} \]
Answer: The dragster’s final velocity is approximately \(145 \text{ m/s}\).

This is about 324 miles per hour! Note that when taking the square root, you would generally get two answers (positive and negative). Here, since the dragster is speeding up in the positive direction, we take the positive root. This equation also illustrates why high-speed stops require much longer distances, as stopping distance is proportional to \(v_0^2\).

title: Physics
section: Problem: How Far Does a Car Go? (Example 3.10)
text:
Problem: How Far Does a Car Go? (Example 3.10)
On dry concrete, a car can accelerate opposite to the motion at \(7.00 \text{ m/s}^2\). On wet concrete, it’s only \(5.00 \text{ m/s}^2\). The car is initially moving at \(30.0 \text{ m/s}\).
(a) Find the stopping distance on dry concrete. (b) Find the stopping distance on wet concrete. (c) Repeat (a) and (b), but account for a reaction time of \(0.500 \text{ s}\) before braking.

This is a multi-part problem that requires careful application of the kinematic equations. For part (c), remember that during reaction time, the car moves at a constant velocity, and only then does acceleration (braking) begin.

title: Physics
section: Solution: How Far Does a Car Go? (Part a & b)
text:
Solution: How Far Does a Car Go? (Part a & b)
Strategy:

Define forward direction as positive (+).
Knowns: \(v_0 = 30.0 \text{ m/s}\), \(v = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (stops).
Unknown: Displacement (\(x - x_0\)).
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\) (since time is unknown).
Solve for \((x - x_0)\): \((x - x_0) = \frac{v^2 - v_0^2}{2a}\).


Figure 3.22: Car stopping distance sketch.
(a) Dry Concrete: \(a = -7.00 \text{ m/s}^2\) (negative because opposite to \(v_0\)).
\[ (x - x_0)_{\text{dry}} = \frac{(0 \text{ m/s})^2 - (30.0 \text{ m/s})^2}{2(-7.00 \text{ m/s}^2)} = \frac{-900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2}{-14.00 \text{ m/s}^2} = 64.3 \text{ m} \]
Answer (a): Stopping distance on dry concrete is \(64.3 \text{ m}\).
(b) Wet Concrete: \(a = -5.00 \text{ m/s}^2\).
\[ (x - x_0)_{\text{wet}} = \frac{(0 \text{ m/s})^2 - (30.0 \text{ m/s})^2}{2(-5.00 \text{ m/s}^2)} = \frac{-900 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2}{-10.00 \text{ m/s}^2} = 90.0 \text{ m} \]
Answer (b): Stopping distance on wet concrete is \(90.0 \text{ m}\).

Notice how the reduced braking acceleration on wet concrete significantly increases the stopping distance. This is why driving slower in rain is critical.

title: Physics
section: Solution: How Far Does a Car Go? (Part c)
text:
Solution: How Far Does a Car Go? (Part c)
(c) With \(0.500 \text{ s}\) reaction time: During reaction time, velocity is constant (\(a = 0\)).

\(v_0 = 30.0 \text{ m/s}\)
\(t_{\text{reaction}} = 0.500 \text{ s}\)
Equation: \(x = x_0 + v_0t\) (since \(a=0\)).

\[ x_{\text{reaction}} = (30.0 \text{ m/s})(0.500 \text{ s}) = 15.0 \text{ m} \]
Now add this reaction distance to the braking distances:

Total distance (dry): \(64.3 \text{ m} + 15.0 \text{ m} = 79.3 \text{ m}\)
Total distance (wet): \(90.0 \text{ m} + 15.0 \text{ m} = 105.0 \text{ m}\)


Figure 3.23: Total stopping distance including reaction time.
Answer (c): Total stopping distance is \(79.3 \text{ m}\) (dry) and \(105.0 \text{ m}\) (wet).

Reaction time adds a significant amount to the stopping distance. This emphasizes why attentive driving and proper following distance are crucial for safety, especially at higher speeds and in adverse conditions.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating Time (Freeway Ramp)
A car merges onto a freeway on a \(200 \text{ m}\) long ramp. Its initial velocity is \(10.0 \text{ m/s}\) and it accelerates at \(2.00 \text{ m/s}^2\).
How long does it take the car to travel the \(200 \text{ m}\) up the ramp?

We’re looking for time, given initial position, initial velocity, acceleration, and final position. Which kinematic equation fits this scenario?

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Calculating Time (Freeway Ramp)
Strategy:

Define coordinate system: Let start of ramp be \(x_0 = 0\).
Identify knowns:

Initial position (\(x_0 = 0 \text{ m}\))
Initial velocity (\(v_0 = 10.0 \text{ m/s}\))
Acceleration (\(a = 2.00 \text{ m/s}^2\))
Final position (\(x = 200 \text{ m}\))

Identify unknown: Time (\(t\)).
Choose equation: \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\).


Figure 3.24: Car on a freeway ramp.
Solution: Substitute values into \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\): \[ 200 = 0 + (10.0)t + \frac{1}{2}(2.00)t^2 \] \[ 200 = 10t + t^2 \] Rearrange into a quadratic equation: \[ t^2 + 10t - 200 = 0 \] Use the quadratic formula \(t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\): \[ t = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{(10)^2 - 4(1)(-200)}}{2(1)} \] \[ t = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{100 + 800}}{2} = \frac{-10 \pm \sqrt{900}}{2} = \frac{-10 \pm 30}{2} \] Two solutions: \(t = \frac{-10 + 30}{2} = 10 \text{ s}\) and \(t = \frac{-10 - 30}{2} = -20 \text{ s}\). Time cannot be negative, so we discard \(t = -20 \text{ s}\).
Answer: It takes \(10.0 \text{ s}\) for the car to travel \(200 \text{ m}\).

When you encounter a quadratic equation, always consider both solutions and determine if both are physically meaningful. In this case, negative time is not valid for the physical scenario described.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.5
Problem: A rocket accelerates at a rate of \(20 \text{ m/s}^2\) during launch.
How long does it take the rocket to reach a velocity of \(400 \text{ m/s}\)?

Assume the rocket starts from rest. We have acceleration, final velocity, and initial velocity. We need to find time.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.5 - Solution
Strategy:

Assume initial velocity \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\) (starts from rest).
Knowns: \(a = 20 \text{ m/s}^2\), \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\), \(v = 400 \text{ m/s}\).
Unknown: Time (\(t\)).
Equation: \(v = v_0 + at\).

Solution:
\[ 400 \text{ m/s} = 0 \text{ m/s} + (20 \text{ m/s}^2)t \] \[ t = \frac{400 \text{ m/s}}{20 \text{ m/s}^2} = 20 \text{ s} \]
Answer: It takes \(20 \text{ s}\) for the rocket to reach \(400 \text{ m/s}\).

This is a direct application of the velocity-time equation. Engineers use this type of calculation to determine how quickly a vehicle can achieve a target speed.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Cheetah Catching a Gazelle (Example 3.13)
A cheetah hides behind a bush. A gazelle runs past at a constant speed of \(10 \text{ m/s}\). At that instant, the cheetah accelerates from rest at \(4 \text{ m/s}^2\) to catch the gazelle.
(a) How long does it take the cheetah to catch the gazelle? (b) What is the displacement of the gazelle and cheetah when caught?

Here, we have two objects with different types of motion (constant velocity vs. constant acceleration). The common parameter when the cheetah catches the gazelle is their position and time.

title: Physics
section: Strategy & Solution (Part a): Cheetah Catching Gazelle
text:
Strategy & Solution (Part a): Cheetah Catching Gazelle
Strategy:

Define coordinate system: Let \(x_0 = 0\) for both animals at \(t = 0\).
Equations of motion:

Gazelle (constant velocity): \(x_g = x_{0g} + v_g t \Rightarrow x_g = (10 \text{ m/s})t\)
Cheetah (constant acceleration from rest): \(x_c = x_{0c} + v_{0c}t + \frac{1}{2}a_c t^2 \Rightarrow x_c = \frac{1}{2}(4 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 = (2 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2\)

Common parameter: When the cheetah catches the gazelle, their positions are equal (\(x_g = x_c\)).
Solve simultaneously for time (t):

Solution (a): Set \(x_g = x_c\):
\[ (10 \text{ m/s})t = (2 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 \]
Rearrange and solve for \(t\):
\[ (2 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 - (10 \text{ m/s})t = 0 \]
\[ t((2 \text{ m/s}^2)t - (10 \text{ m/s})) = 0 \]
Two solutions: \(t = 0 \text{ s}\) (start) or \((2 \text{ m/s}^2)t = 10 \text{ m/s}\).
\[ t = \frac{10 \text{ m/s}}{2 \text{ m/s}^2} = 5 \text{ s} \]
Answer (a): It takes \(5 \text{ s}\) for the cheetah to catch the gazelle.

The \(t=0\) solution simply represents the moment they are at the same position at the start. The \(t=5s\) solution is when the cheetah catches the gazelle. This technique of setting positions equal is fundamental for pursuit problems.

title: Physics
text:
Solution (Part b): Cheetah Catching Gazelle
(b) What is the displacement of the gazelle and cheetah?

Use either the gazelle’s or the cheetah’s equation of motion with \(t = 5 \text{ s}\). They should yield the same displacement.

Using Gazelle’s equation:
\[ x_g = (10 \text{ m/s})t = (10 \text{ m/s})(5 \text{ s}) = 50 \text{ m} \]
Using Cheetah’s equation:
\[ x_c = (2 \text{ m/s}^2)t^2 = (2 \text{ m/s}^2)(5 \text{ s})^2 = (2 \text{ m/s}^2)(25 \text{ s}^2) = 50 \text{ m} \]
Answer (b): The displacement for both is \(50 \text{ m}\).

The consistency of the displacement calculation from both equations confirms the correctness of our time calculation. This type of problem-solving approach is invaluable in many engineering fields.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.6
Problem: A bicycle has a constant velocity of \(10 \text{ m/s}\). A person starts from rest and begins to run to catch up to the bicycle in \(30 \text{ s}\). At \(t=30 \text{ s}\), the bicycle is at the same position as the person.
What is the acceleration of the person?

This is another two-body pursuit problem, but this time we are solving for an unknown acceleration. Set up the equations for both the bicycle and the person, then use the common information (position and time) to solve for the person’s acceleration.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.6 - Solution
Strategy:

Define coordinate system: Let \(x_0 = 0\) for both at \(t = 0\).
Equations of motion:

Bicycle (constant velocity): \(x_b = x_{0b} + v_b t \Rightarrow x_b = (10 \text{ m/s})t\)
Person (constant acceleration from rest): \(x_p = x_{0p} + v_{0p}t + \frac{1}{2}a_p t^2 \Rightarrow x_p = \frac{1}{2}a_p t^2\)

Common parameter: At \(t = 30 \text{ s}\), their positions are equal (\(x_b = x_p\)).
Solve for acceleration (\(a_p\)):

Solution: First, find the position of the bicycle at \(t=30 \text{ s}\): \[ x_b = (10 \text{ m/s})(30 \text{ s}) = 300 \text{ m} \]
Since the person is at the same position at \(t=30 \text{ s}\), \(x_p = 300 \text{ m}\). Now use the person’s equation of motion: \[ x_p = \frac{1}{2}a_p t^2 \] \[ 300 \text{ m} = \frac{1}{2}a_p (30 \text{ s})^2 \] \[ 300 \text{ m} = \frac{1}{2}a_p (900 \text{ s}^2) \] \[ 300 \text{ m} = (450 \text{ s}^2)a_p \] \[ a_p = \frac{300 \text{ m}}{450 \text{ s}^2} = \frac{2}{3} \text{ m/s}^2 \approx 0.67 \text{ m/s}^2 \]
Answer: The acceleration of the person is approximately \(0.67 \text{ m/s}^2\).

This acceleration is achievable for an athletic person. It shows how even a relatively small, constant acceleration can cover significant distances over time.

title: Physics
text:
Key Equations (Constant \(a\))







Equation
Description




\(x = x_0 + \bar{v}t\)
Position from average velocity and time


\(\bar{v} = \frac{v_0 + v}{2}\)
Average velocity with constant acceleration


\(v = v_0 + at\)
Final velocity from initial, acceleration, time


\(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\)
Final position from initial, velocity, acceleration, time


\(v^2 = v_0^2 + 2a(x - x_0)\)
Final velocity from initial, acceleration, displacement




These five equations are your go-to tools. Practice using them to become proficient in solving a wide range of kinematics problems.

title: Physics
text:
Key Terms







Term
Definition




Constant Acceleration
A state of motion where the rate of change of velocity remains uniform over time.


Kinematic Equations
A set of five mathematical equations that describe the motion of an object under constant acceleration.


Initial Position (\(x_0\))
The starting location of an object in a given coordinate system.


Initial Velocity (\(v_0\))
The velocity of an object at the beginning of a time interval.


Final Position (\(x\))
The location of an object at the end of a time interval.


Final Velocity (\(v\))
The velocity of an object at the end of a time interval.


Two-Body Pursuit Problem
A problem involving two objects whose motions are interdependent, requiring simultaneous solution of their kinematic equations.




Familiarize yourself with these terms. A clear understanding of the vocabulary is just as important as mastering the equations.

title: Physics
text:
The Universal Nature of Gravity

A remarkable fact: if air resistance and friction are negligible, all objects fall toward the center of Earth with the same constant acceleration, regardless of their mass.
This was famously demonstrated by Galileo Galilei, and later by astronaut David R. Scott on the Moon.


Figure 3.26: Hammer and feather falling in air vs. vacuum.






Note


In the real world, air resistance causes lighter, less dense objects to fall slower. Our free-fall model ignores this for simplicity.




This is a cornerstone concept in physics. It’s counter-intuitive because our everyday experience is dominated by air resistance. But in a vacuum, a feather and a bowling ball fall at the same rate.

title: Physics
section: Kinematic Equations for Objects in Free Fall
text:
Kinematic Equations for Objects in Free Fall
We use the same kinematic equations for constant acceleration, but substitute \(y\) for \(x\) and \(a\) with either \(+g\) or \(-g\).
Assuming upward is positive, so \(a = -g\):

\(v = v_0 - gt\)
\(y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\)
\(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\)







Tip


These are simply the constant acceleration equations with vertical displacement (\(y\)) and acceleration (\(a=-g\)). Remember, if you define downward as positive, then \(a=+g\).




These equations are fundamental for analyzing vertical motion. It’s crucial to understand the implications of the signs and the direction of your chosen coordinate system.

title: Physics
text:
Problem-Solving Strategy: Free Fall

Define your coordinate system: Choose which direction is positive (usually upward) and state it clearly. This determines the sign of \(g\).
Draw a sketch: Visualize the motion and label initial/final positions, velocities, and the direction of acceleration.
Record knowns and unknowns: List all given values and what you need to find.
Select appropriate equations: Choose from the kinematic equations those that contain your knowns and the single unknown you want to solve for. You may need to use multiple equations.


This structured approach helps minimize errors and ensures you apply the principles correctly. A clear diagram is often the most helpful first step.

title: Physics
section: Problem: Free Fall of a Ball (Example 3.14)
text:
Problem: Free Fall of a Ball (Example 3.14)
A ball is thrown downward from the top of a \(98 \text{ m}\) high building with an initial velocity of \(4.9 \text{ m/s}\) downward.
(a) How much time elapses before the ball reaches the ground? (b) What is the velocity when it arrives at the ground?

Figure 3.27: Ball thrown downward from a building.

Here, the ball is thrown downwards, so its initial velocity will be negative if we choose upward as positive. The final position will also be negative.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part a)
text:
Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part a)
Strategy:

Coordinate system: Let upward be positive (+y). Origin (\(y_0=0\)) at the top of the building.
Knowns:

Initial position (\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\))
Initial velocity (\(v_0 = -4.9 \text{ m/s}\)) (downward is negative)
Acceleration (\(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\))
Final position (\(y = -98 \text{ m}\)) (ground is 98 m below origin)

Unknown: Time (\(t\)).
Equation: \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \Rightarrow y = y_0 + v_0t - \frac{1}{2}gt^2\).

Solution (a): \[ -98 = 0 + (-4.9)t - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2 \] \[ -98 = -4.9t - 4.9t^2 \] Rearrange into a quadratic equation: \[ 4.9t^2 + 4.9t - 98 = 0 \] Divide by 4.9: \[ t^2 + t - 20 = 0 \] Using quadratic formula \(t = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\): \[ t = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1^2 - 4(1)(-20)}}{2(1)} = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{1 + 80}}{2} = \frac{-1 \pm \sqrt{81}}{2} = \frac{-1 \pm 9}{2} \] Solutions: \(t = \frac{-1 + 9}{2} = 4 \text{ s}\) or \(t = \frac{-1 - 9}{2} = -5 \text{ s}\). We choose the positive physically meaningful time.
Answer (a): The ball reaches the ground in \(4.0 \text{ s}\).

The negative time solution \((-5s)\) corresponds to when the ball would have been at \(y=0\) if it had been thrown upward from the ground and then passed the top of the building at \(4.9 m/s\) downwards. For our scenario, only the positive time is relevant.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part b)
text:
Solution: Free Fall of a Ball (Part b)
Strategy (b):

Knowns: From part (a), \(v_0 = -4.9 \text{ m/s}\), \(a = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\), \(t = 4.0 \text{ s}\).
Unknown: Final velocity (\(v\)).
Equation: \(v = v_0 + at \Rightarrow v = v_0 - gt\).

Solution (b): \[ v = -4.9 \text{ m/s} - (9.8 \text{ m/s}^2)(4.0 \text{ s}) \] \[ v = -4.9 \text{ m/s} - 39.2 \text{ m/s} \] \[ v = -44.1 \text{ m/s} \]
Answer (b): The velocity when it arrives at the ground is \(-44.1 \text{ m/s}\).

The negative sign confirms that the ball is moving downward when it hits the ground. This problem emphasizes the importance of a consistent coordinate system and careful sign convention.

title: Physics
section: Problem: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Example 3.15)
text:
Problem: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Example 3.15)
A batter hits a baseball straight upward. The ball is caught \(5.0 \text{ s}\) after it is struck, at the same location.
(a) What is the initial velocity of the ball?
(b) What is the maximum height the ball reaches?
(c) How long does it take to reach the maximum height?
(d) What is the acceleration at the top of its path?
(e) What is the velocity of the ball when it is caught?

Figure 3.28: Baseball hit straight up.

This is a classic free-fall problem involving symmetrical motion (up and down to the same height). We’ll analyze different points in its trajectory.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part a, b, c)
text:
Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part a, b, c)
Strategy:

Coordinate system: Upward is positive (+y). Origin (\(y_0=0\)) at home plate.
Knowns: \(y_0 = 0\), \(y = 0\) (caught at same height), \(t = 5.0 \text{ s}\), \(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\).

(a) Initial velocity (\(v_0\)): Use \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\): \[ 0 = 0 + v_0(5.0) - \frac{1}{2}(9.8)(5.0)^2 \] \[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - 4.9(25.0) \] \[ 0 = 5.0v_0 - 122.5 \] \[ v_0 = \frac{122.5}{5.0} = 24.5 \text{ m/s} \] Answer (a): Initial velocity is \(24.5 \text{ m/s}\).
(b) Maximum height (\(y_{max}\)): At max height, \(v=0\).
Use \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\): \[ 0^2 = (24.5)^2 - 2(9.8)(y_{max} - 0) \] \[ 0 = 600.25 - 19.6 y_{max} \] \[ y_{max} = \frac{600.25}{19.6} = 30.6 \text{ m} \] Answer (b): Maximum height is \(30.6 \text{ m}\).
(c) Time to reach maximum height (\(t_{max}\)): At max height, \(v=0\).
Use \(v = v_0 - gt\): \[ 0 = 24.5 - 9.8 t_{max} \] \[ t_{max} = \frac{24.5}{9.8} = 2.5 \text{ s} \] Answer (c): Time to reach maximum height is \(2.5 \text{ s}\).

Notice how the time to reach maximum height (2.5s) is exactly half the total flight time (5.0s). This is a characteristic of symmetrical free-fall motion starting and ending at the same height.

title: Physics
section: Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part d, e)
text:
Solution: Vertical Motion of a Baseball (Part d, e)
(d) Acceleration at the top of its path:

Throughout free fall, the acceleration due to gravity is constant.

Answer (d): The acceleration at the top of its path is \(-9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\).
(Even when \(v=0\), the velocity is still changing, meaning acceleration is still present.)
(e) Velocity of the ball when it is caught:
Use \(v = v_0 - gt\): \[ v = 24.5 \text{ m/s} - (9.8 \text{ m/s}^2)(5.0 \text{ s}) \] \[ v = 24.5 \text{ m/s} - 49.0 \text{ m/s} = -24.5 \text{ m/s} \]
Answer (e): The velocity when caught is \(-24.5 \text{ m/s}\).

The ball returns with the same speed but opposite direction as its initial velocity. This is another key property of symmetrical free fall where air resistance is negligible. This is a very important concept for understanding projectile motion.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.7
Problem: A chunk of ice breaks off a glacier and falls \(30.0 \text{ m}\) before it hits the water. Assuming it falls freely (no air resistance):
(a) How long does it take to hit the water?
(b) Which quantity increases faster, the speed of the ice chunk or its distance traveled?

Here, we’re dropping an object, so initial velocity is zero. We need to find time and compare the rate of change of speed vs. distance.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.7 - Solution
Strategy:

Coordinate system: Let downward be positive (+y). Origin (\(y_0=0\)) at the point where the ice breaks off.
Knowns: \(y_0 = 0\), \(y = 30.0 \text{ m}\), \(v_0 = 0 \text{ m/s}\), \(a = +g = +9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\).

(a) How long does it take to hit the water? Use \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\): \[ 30.0 = 0 + (0)t + \frac{1}{2}(9.8)t^2 \] \[ 30.0 = 4.9t^2 \] \[ t^2 = \frac{30.0}{4.9} \approx 6.12 \] \[ t = \sqrt{6.12} \approx 2.47 \text{ s} \]
Answer (a): It takes approximately \(2.47 \text{ s}\) to hit the water.
(b) Which quantity increases faster, the speed of the ice chunk or its distance traveled?

Speed: \(v = v_0 + gt = gt\) (linear increase with time).
Distance traveled: \(y = y_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}gt^2 = \frac{1}{2}gt^2\) (quadratic increase with time).

A quadratic function increases faster than a linear function for \(t > 0\).
Answer (b): The distance traveled increases faster.

This distinction is important. While speed increases steadily, the accumulated distance grows much more rapidly due to the accelerating motion.

title: Physics
text:
Example 3.16: Rocket Booster
A small rocket with a booster blasts off and heads straight upward. When at a height of \(5.0 \text{ km}\) and velocity of \(200.0 \text{ m/s}\), it releases its booster.
(a) What is the maximum height the booster attains (relative to the release point)?
(b) What is the velocity of the booster at a height of \(6.0 \text{ km}\) (relative to Earth’s surface)?

Figure 3.29: Rocket releasing its booster.

This problem introduces an initial altitude. We need to be careful with our coordinate system and reference points. For part (a), the origin can be the release point. For part (b), we’ll need to consider the height from Earth’s surface.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Rocket Booster (Part a)
Strategy (a): Max height relative to release point

Coordinate system: Let upward be positive (+y). Origin (\(y_0=0\)) at the booster release point (\(5.0 \text{ km}\) above Earth).
Knowns:

Initial position (\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\))
Initial velocity (\(v_0 = 200.0 \text{ m/s}\))
Acceleration (\(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\))
At max height, final velocity (\(v = 0 \text{ m/s}\)).

Unknown: Maximum height (\(y_{max}\)).
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\).

Solution (a):
\[ 0^2 = (200.0)^2 - 2(9.8)(y_{max} - 0) \] \[ 0 = 40000 - 19.6 y_{max} \] \[ y_{max} = \frac{40000}{19.6} \approx 2040.8 \text{ m} \approx 2.04 \text{ km} \]
The maximum height the booster attains relative to the release point is \(2.04 \text{ km}\).
The maximum height from Earth’s surface is \(5.0 \text{ km} + 2.04 \text{ km} = 7.04 \text{ km}\).
Answer (a): The maximum height the booster attains is approximately \(2.04 \text{ km}\) above the release point (or \(7.04 \text{ km}\) above Earth’s surface).

It’s important to be clear about the reference frame. The question specified “attains”, so the maximum height above the ground would be the release height plus the calculated additional height.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Rocket Booster (Part b)
Strategy (b): Velocity at \(6.0 \text{ km}\) from Earth’s surface

Coordinate system: Upward is positive (+y). Origin (\(y_0=0\)) at the booster release point.
Knowns:

Initial position (\(y_0 = 0 \text{ m}\))
Initial velocity (\(v_0 = 200.0 \text{ m/s}\))
Acceleration (\(a = -g = -9.8 \text{ m/s}^2\))
Target height: \(6.0 \text{ km}\) from Earth. Since the release point is \(5.0 \text{ km}\) from Earth, the target height relative to the release point is \(y = 6.0 \text{ km} - 5.0 \text{ km} = 1.0 \text{ km} = 1000 \text{ m}\).

Unknown: Velocity (\(v\)) at this height.
Equation: \(v^2 = v_0^2 - 2g(y - y_0)\).

Solution (b):
\[ v^2 = (200.0 \text{ m/s})^2 - 2(9.8 \text{ m/s}^2)(1000 \text{ m} - 0) \] \[ v^2 = 40000 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 - 19600 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \] \[ v^2 = 20400 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2 \] \[ v = \pm \sqrt{20400 \text{ m}^2/\text{s}^2} \approx \pm 142.8 \text{ m/s} \]
Answer (b): The velocity of the booster at \(6.0 \text{ km}\) is approximately \(\pm 142.8 \text{ m/s}\).

The \(\pm\) result is significant. The positive value (\(+142.8 \text{ m/s}\)) corresponds to the booster’s velocity as it moves upward through \(6.0 \text{ km}\). The negative value (\(-142.8 \text{ m/s}\)) corresponds to its velocity as it moves downward through \(6.0 \text{ km}\) after reaching its peak. This correctly accounts for the two times the booster will be at that altitude.

title: Physics
text:
Review: Kinematic Functions and Derivatives
Recall from previous sections:

Velocity is the derivative of position with respect to time: \[ v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \]
Acceleration is the derivative of velocity with respect to time: \[ a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt} \]

This means we can also think of acceleration as the second derivative of position: \[ a(t) = \frac{d^2x(t)}{dt^2} \]

These are the fundamental relationships. Now, we’ll reverse this process using integration to go from acceleration back to velocity and then to position.

title: Physics
text:
Kinematic Equations from Integral Calculus
To go “backward” from acceleration to velocity, and from velocity to position, we use integration.
1. From Acceleration to Velocity:
Given \(a(t) = \frac{dv(t)}{dt}\), we integrate both sides with respect to time: \[ \int \frac{dv(t)}{dt} dt = \int a(t) dt \] \[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt + C_1 \] where \(C_1\) is the constant of integration. We can find \(C_1\) using an initial condition, typically \(v(0) = v_0\).
2. From Velocity to Position:
Given \(v(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt}\), we integrate both sides with respect to time: \[ \int \frac{dx(t)}{dt} dt = \int v(t) dt \] \[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt + C_2 \] where \(C_2\) is another constant of integration, found using an initial condition, typically \(x(0) = x_0\).

The constants of integration represent the initial velocity and initial position, respectively. These are determined by the specific conditions of the problem.

title: Physics
section: Deriving Constant Acceleration Equations using Integrals
text:
Deriving Constant Acceleration Equations using Integrals
Let’s derive the familiar kinematic equations assuming constant acceleration, \(a(t) = a\):
Step 1: Find Velocity \(v(t)\) \[ v(t) = \int a dt + C_1 \] Since \(a\) is constant: \[ v(t) = at + C_1 \] To find \(C_1\), use the initial condition: at \(t=0\), \(v(0) = v_0\). \[ v_0 = a(0) + C_1 \implies C_1 = v_0 \] So, the velocity function is: \[ v(t) = v_0 + at \] (This is the familiar \(v = v_0 + at\) equation).
Step 2: Find Position \(x(t)\)
Now integrate the velocity function \(v(t) = v_0 + at\): \[ x(t) = \int (v_0 + at) dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 + C_2 \] To find \(C_2\), use the initial condition: at \(t=0\), \(x(0) = x_0\). \[ x_0 = v_0(0) + \frac{1}{2}a(0)^2 + C_2 \implies C_2 = x_0 \] So, the position function is: \[ x(t) = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2 \] (This is the familiar \(x = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2\) equation).

This derivation shows how integral calculus provides a more fundamental way to obtain the kinematic equations. It also prepares us for situations where ‘a’ is not constant.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Motion of a Motorboat (Example 3.17)
A motorboat is traveling at a constant velocity of \(5.0 \text{ m/s}\). At \(t=0\), it starts to accelerate in the opposite direction. Its acceleration is given by: \[ a(t) = -\frac{1}{4}t \text{ m/s}^3 \]
(a) What is the velocity function of the motorboat?
(b) At what time does the velocity reach zero?
(c) What is the position function of the motorboat?
(d) What is the displacement from \(t=0\) to when the velocity is zero?
(e) Graph the velocity and position functions.

This problem has a time-dependent acceleration. We’ll use the integral method to find the velocity and position functions, and then analyze the boat’s motion. The units of acceleration are important here, m/s^3, to ensure consistency after integration.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part a)
(a) What is the velocity function of the motorboat?
Strategy:

Integrate the acceleration function \(a(t)\) to find \(v(t)\).
Use the initial condition \(v(0) = 5.0 \text{ m/s}\) to find the constant of integration.

Solution (a): \[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt + C_1 \] \[ v(t) = \int \left( -\frac{1}{4}t \right) dt + C_1 \] \[ v(t) = -\frac{1}{4} \left( \frac{t^2}{2} \right) + C_1 \] \[ v(t) = -\frac{1}{8}t^2 + C_1 \] Now, apply the initial condition \(v(0) = 5.0 \text{ m/s}\): \[ 5.0 = -\frac{1}{8}(0)^2 + C_1 \implies C_1 = 5.0 \text{ m/s} \] So, the velocity function is: \[ v(t) = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \] (The units are implicitly \(\text{m/s}\) for the constant and \(\text{m/s}^3 \cdot \text{s}^2 = \text{m/s}\) for the second term, so \(v(t)\) is in \(\text{m/s}\)).
Answer (a): \(v(t) = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \text{ (m/s)}\).

Remember to always include the constant of integration after performing indefinite integrals and use initial conditions to solve for it. The units are also crucial to check for consistency.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part b)
(b) At what time does the velocity reach zero?
Strategy: Set \(v(t) = 0\) and solve for \(t\).
Solution (b):
We have \(v(t) = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2\).
Set \(v(t) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \] \[ \frac{1}{8}t^2 = 5.0 \] \[ t^2 = 5.0 \times 8 = 40.0 \] \[ t = \sqrt{40.0} \approx 6.32 \text{ s} \]
(We take the positive root for time).
Answer (b): The velocity reaches zero at approximately \(6.3 \text{ s}\).

This is the moment when the boat momentarily stops before potentially reversing direction if the acceleration continues. This point is often a critical analysis point in physics problems.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part c)
(c) What is the position function of the motorboat?
Strategy:

Integrate the velocity function \(v(t)\) to find \(x(t)\).
Assume the initial position \(x(0) = 0\) (starting point) to find the constant of integration.

Solution (c): \[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = \int \left( 5.0 - \frac{1}{8}t^2 \right) dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{8} \left( \frac{t^3}{3} \right) + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3 + C_2 \] Now, apply the initial condition \(x(0) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5.0(0) - \frac{1}{24}(0)^3 + C_2 \implies C_2 = 0 \] So, the position function is: \[ x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3 \]
(The units are implicitly meters).
Answer (c): \(x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3 \text{ (m)}\).

We assumed \(x(0)=0\) which is a common and convenient choice when analyzing displacement from the start of the motion.

title: Physics
text:
Solution: Motorboat Motion (Part d)
(d) What is the displacement of the motorboat from \(t=0\) to when the velocity is zero?
Strategy: Evaluate the position function \(x(t)\) at the time when \(v(t)=0\) (which we found in part b).
Solution (d):
From part (b), velocity reaches zero at \(t \approx 6.32 \text{ s}\).
Substitute \(t = 6.32 \text{ s}\) into the position function \(x(t) = 5.0t - \frac{1}{24}t^3\): \[ x(6.32) = 5.0(6.32) - \frac{1}{24}(6.32)^3 \] \[ x(6.32) = 31.6 - \frac{1}{24}(252.88) \] \[ x(6.32) = 31.6 - 10.54 \approx 21.06 \text{ m} \]
Answer (d): The displacement is approximately \(21.1 \text{ m}\).

This displacement represents the maximum distance the boat travels in the positive direction before it begins to move backward if the acceleration pattern continues.

The velocity graph (top) shows \(v(t)\) decreasing from \(5.0 \text{ m/s}\) to zero at \(t \approx 6.3 \text{ s}\), then becoming negative, indicating a change in direction.
The position graph (bottom) shows \(x(t)\) increasing to a maximum at \(t \approx 6.3 \text{ s}\), corresponding to when the velocity is zero. After this, position decreases as the boat reverses direction.

title: Physics
text:
Check Your Understanding 3.8 - Solution
Given:

Starts from rest: \(v(0) = 0\).
Acceleration function: \(a(t) = \left( 5 - \frac{1}{10}t \right)\).
Assume \(x(0) = 0\).

(a) Velocity function: \[ v(t) = \int a(t) dt + C_1 = \int \left( 5 - \frac{1}{10}t \right) dt + C_1 \] \[ v(t) = 5t - \frac{1}{10}\frac{t^2}{2} + C_1 = 5t - \frac{1}{20}t^2 + C_1 \] Using \(v(0) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5(0) - \frac{1}{20}(0)^2 + C_1 \implies C_1 = 0 \]
Answer (a): \(v(t) = 5t - \frac{1}{20}t^2 \text{ (m/s)}\).
(b) Position function:
\[ x(t) = \int v(t) dt + C_2 = \int \left( 5t - \frac{1}{20}t^2 \right) dt + C_2 \] \[ x(t) = 5\frac{t^2}{2} - \frac{1}{20}\frac{t^3}{3} + C_2 = \frac{5}{2}t^2 - \frac{1}{60}t^3 + C_2 \] Using \(x(0) = 0\): \[ 0 = \frac{5}{2}(0)^2 - \frac{1}{60}(0)^3 + C_2 \implies C_2 = 0 \] Answer (b): \(x(t) = \frac{5}{2}t^2 - \frac{1}{60}t^3 \text{ (m)}\).
(c) When is the velocity zero?
Set \(v(t) = 0\): \[ 0 = 5t - \frac{1}{20}t^2 \] \[ t \left( 5 - \frac{1}{20}t \right) = 0 \] Two solutions: \(t=0\) (at rest initially) or \(5 - \frac{1}{20}t = 0\). \[ \frac{1}{20}t = 5 \implies t = 100 \text{ s} \]
Answer (c): The velocity is zero at \(t=0 \text{ s}\) and \(t=100 \text{ s}\).

The interpretation of the two times when velocity is zero is crucial: \(t=0\) is the start from rest, and \(t=100s\) is when the particle momentarily stops before potentially reversing direction due to the changing acceleration.

Displacement Vector


The displacement vector Δr is the change in position of a particle. If a particle moves from position P₁ at time t₁ to position P₂ at time t₂, its displacement is:
\[ \Delta \mathbf{r} = \mathbf{r}(t_2) - \mathbf{r}(t_1) \]

Independence of Perpendicular Motions
A crucial insight for analyzing multidimensional motion is that motion along perpendicular axes are independent of each other.
This means:

Motion along the x-axis is only affected by forces acting along the x-axis.
Motion along the y-axis is only affected by forces acting along the y-axis.
Motion along the z-axis is only affected by forces acting along the z-axis.

This principle allows us to break down complex 2D or 3D motion into simpler 1D problems.

This is perhaps the most powerful concept when extending from 1D to multi-D kinematics.
It simplifies analysis immensely. For example, when analyzing projectile motion, we treat the horizontal (x) and vertical (y) components separately. The horizontal motion is governed by initial horizontal velocity and no horizontal forces (ignoring air resistance), while the vertical motion is governed by gravity and the initial vertical velocity.
These two independent motions combine to produce the resultant trajectory.

title: Physics

Introduction to Multidimensional Motion
To describe motion in two and three dimensions, we must first establish a coordinate system and a convention for the axes. We generally use the coordinates x, y, and z to locate a particle at point P(x, y, z) in three dimensions.
If the particle is moving, the variables x, y, and z are functions of time (t):
x = x(t), y = y(t), z = z(t).

In one dimension, we only needed a single axis (e.g., the x-axis) and a sign (positive/negative) to describe position.
Now, for 2D or 3D motion, we need multiple axes and a clear convention.
The standard is a right-handed coordinate system, which we’ll assume unless stated otherwise.
This means if you point your right thumb along the positive z-axis, your fingers curl from the positive x-axis to the positive y-axis.
The coordinates x, y, and z are not fixed values; they change as the object moves, hence they are functions of time.

Its components, x(t), y(t), and z(t), tell us how far the particle is along each axis.
The use of unit vectors \(\hat{i}\), \(\hat{j}\), \(\hat{k}\) is standard and simplifies vector notation.

A satellite is in a circular polar orbit around Earth. At time \(t_1\), it is directly over the North Pole. At a later time \(t_2\), it is at −45° latitude.

Assume:

Satellite altitude = 400 km.
Origin is at the center of Earth.
y-axis points North, x-axis points East.


This problem applies the concept of displacement to a realistic engineering scenario: orbital mechanics.

title: Physics
text:
Satellite Displacement - Strategy & Solution (Part 1)
Strategy:

Visualize the orbit and positions in a 2D coordinate system (since orbit is circular and we can align it with relevant axes).
Define the position vectors r→(t₁) and r→(t₂) using the given radius and angles.
Calculate the displacement vector Δr = r→(t₂) - r→(t₁).
Determine the magnitude and direction of Δr.

Solution:
The orbital radius is \(R = R_E + \text{altitude} = 6370 \text{ km} + 400 \text{ km} = 6770\) km.
At \(t_1\) (over North Pole):
The satellite is on the positive y-axis. \[ \mathbf{r}(t_1) = 0\hat{i} + 6770\hat{j} \text{ km} \]
At \(t_2\) (at -45° latitude):
Latitude of -45° means an angle of \(90^\circ - (-45^\circ) = 135^\circ\) from the positive x-axis, or specifically \(-45^\circ\) in a standard polar-to-Cartesian conversion with the x-axis as the reference.
\[ \mathbf{r}(t_2) = R \cos(-45^\circ)\hat{i} + R \sin(-45^\circ)\hat{j} \] \[ \mathbf{r}(t_2) = 6770 \text{ km} \left(\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)\hat{i} + 6770 \text{ km} \left(-\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}\right)\hat{j} \] \[ \mathbf{r}(t_2) \approx 4787\hat{i} - 4787\hat{j} \text{ km} \]

Step 1: We are considering the satellite’s orbit in a plane. Since it’s a polar orbit, we can choose our coordinate system such that the North Pole corresponds to a point on the y-axis. The -45° latitude position can be described using polar coordinates relative to the x-axis.
Step 2: The radius of the orbit is constant. For \(t_1\), the satellite is directly above the North Pole, meaning its position vector points straight up along the y-axis. For \(t_2\), we use trigonometry. A latitude of -45° corresponds to an angle of 45° South of the Equator. In our x-y plane (x=East, y=North), this position can be found using \(R\cos(\theta)\) for x and \(R\sin(\theta)\) for y, where \(\theta\) is measured from the positive x-axis. A -45° latitude means the angle from the positive x-axis is -45°.

text:
Satellite Displacement - Solution (Part 2) & Significance
Solution (cont.):
Now, calculate the displacement vector:
\[ \Delta \mathbf{r} = \mathbf{r}(t_2) - \mathbf{r}(t_1) \] \[ \Delta \mathbf{r} = (4787\hat{i} - 4787\hat{j}) - (0\hat{i} + 6770\hat{j}) \text{ km} \] \[ \Delta \mathbf{r} = 4787\hat{i} - (4787 + 6770)\hat{j} \text{ km} \] \[ \Delta \mathbf{r} = 4787\hat{i} - 11557\hat{j} \text{ km} \]
Magnitude:
\[ |\Delta \mathbf{r}| = \sqrt{(4787)^2 + (-11557)^2} \text{ km} \] \[ |\Delta \mathbf{r}| \approx \sqrt{22.9 \times 10^6 + 133.6 \times 10^6} \text{ km} \] \[ |\Delta \mathbf{r}| \approx \sqrt{156.5 \times 10^6} \text{ km} \approx 12509 \text{ km} \]
Direction:
The angle \(\theta\) with the positive x-axis is: \[ \theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{-11557}{4787}\right) \approx \tan^{-1}(-2.414) \] \[ \theta \approx -67.5^\circ \]

Caption: Figure 4.5 Displacement vector with components, angle, and magnitude.
Significance: The displacement vector is the shortest straight-line distance between the two points in space. The satellite traveled approximately 12,509 km from its position over the North Pole to the −45° latitude position. The angle indicates its general direction relative to the East axis.

Part 2 focuses on the calculation and interpretation.
We subtract the components: x-component of displacement is \(4787 - 0\), and y-component is \(-4787 - 6770\).
For magnitude, we use the Pythagorean theorem in 2D.
For direction, we use the arctangent function, making sure to consider the quadrant (in this case, the negative y-component and positive x-component place it in the fourth quadrant, consistent with -67.5°).
The figure visually represents these components and the resultant displacement vector.
It’s important to note that the actual path along the orbit is longer than this displacement vector.

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Brownian Motion
Brownian motion describes the random movement of particles suspended in a fluid. This motion is three-dimensional. The displacements of a particle undergoing Brownian motion over four consecutive time intervals are given in micrometers (\(\mu\)m):
\(\Delta \mathbf{r}_1 = 2.0\hat{i} + 1.0\hat{j} + 3.0\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta \mathbf{r}_2 = -1.0\hat{i} + 0\hat{j} + 3.0\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta \mathbf{r}_3 = 4.0\hat{i} - 2.0\hat{j} + 1.0\hat{k}\)
\(\Delta \mathbf{r}_4 = -3.0\hat{i} + 1.0\hat{j} + 2.0\hat{k}\)
What is the total displacement of the particle from its starting point?

This example demonstrates adding multiple displacement vectors.
Brownian motion is relevant in many engineering fields, like material science, chemical engineering (diffusion), and even fluid dynamics.
The random nature means we can’t predict the exact path, but we can find the net change in position.

title: Physics
text:
Brownian Motion - Solution
To find the total displacement, we simply add the individual displacement vectors:
\[ \Delta \mathbf{r}_{\text{Total}} = \Delta \mathbf{r}_1 + \Delta \mathbf{r}_2 + \Delta \mathbf{r}_3 + \Delta \mathbf{r}_4 \]
Add the \(\hat{i}\), \(\hat{j}\), and \(\hat{k}\) components separately:
\[ \Delta \mathbf{r}_{\text{Total}} = (2.0 - 1.0 + 4.0 - 3.0)\hat{i} + (1.0 + 0 - 2.0 + 1.0)\hat{j} + (3.0 + 3.0 + 1.0 + 2.0)\hat{k} \text{ } \mu\text{m} \]
\[ \Delta \mathbf{r}_{\text{Total}} = (2.0)\hat{i} + (0)\hat{j} + (9.0)\hat{k} \text{ } \mu\text{m} \]
Magnitude and Direction: \[ |\Delta \mathbf{r}_{\text{Total}}| = \sqrt{(2.0)^2 + (0)^2 + (9.0)^2} = \sqrt{4 + 0 + 81} = \sqrt{85} \approx 9.2 \mu\text{m} \]
The displacement is \(2.0\hat{i} + 9.0\hat{k} \, \mu\text{m}\). This vector lies in the xz-plane.
The angle with the x-axis is \(\theta = \tan^{-1}(9.0/2.0) \approx 77^\circ\).

Caption: Figure 4.6 Trajectory of a particle undergoing random displacements of Brownian motion. The total displacement is shown in red.

The crucial step here is understanding that vector addition is done component-wise.
We sum all the x-components, all the y-components, and all the z-components.
The resulting total displacement vector points from the particle’s initial position to its final position after these four movements.
Notice that the sum of the magnitudes of the individual displacements would be much larger than the magnitude of the total displacement, illustrating the effect of random directions.
This is a key concept in statistical mechanics and transport phenomena.

title: Physics
text:
Velocity Vector - Definition


The instantaneous velocity vector v→(t) is the rate of change of the position vector with respect to time. It is the derivative of the position vector:
\[ \mathbf{v}(t) = \lim_{\Delta t \to 0} \frac{\mathbf{r}(t+\Delta t) - \mathbf{r}(t)}{\Delta t} = \frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} \]
The velocity vector is always tangent to the path of the particle.


Caption: Figure 4.7 A particle moves along a path. As Δt approaches zero, the velocity vector becomes tangent to the path.


This is the direct extension of the 1D definition of instantaneous velocity.
The limit process (\(\Delta t \to 0\)) turns the average velocity over an interval into the instantaneous velocity at a point.
Geometrically, as the two points defining the displacement vector get closer and closer, the displacement vector itself becomes more and more aligned with the tangent to the curve at that point.
This is a fundamental concept for analyzing dynamics, especially in fields like control systems or robotics.

title: Physics
text:
Velocity Vector - Components
We can also express the instantaneous velocity in terms of its components along the coordinate axes:
Since \(\mathbf{r}(t) = x(t)\hat{i} + y(t)\hat{j} + z(t)\hat{k}\), we can write:
\[ \mathbf{v}(t) = v_x(t)\hat{i} + v_y(t)\hat{j} + v_z(t)\hat{k} \]
where the components are:
\[ v_x(t) = \frac{dx(t)}{dt}, \quad v_y(t) = \frac{dy(t)}{dt}, \quad v_z(t) = \frac{dz(t)}{dt} \]
The average velocity \(\mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}}\) over a time interval \(t_1\) to \(t_2\) is:
\[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{\mathbf{r}(t_2) - \mathbf{r}(t_1)}{t_2 - t_1} \]

This component-wise definition is extremely useful for calculations. To find the velocity vector, we just need to differentiate each coordinate function (x(t), y(t), z(t)) with respect to time.
The same applies to acceleration later on.
The average velocity is simply the total displacement divided by the time taken. It’s a vector connecting the start and end points of the motion over that interval.
It’s important to distinguish between instantaneous velocity (at a moment) and average velocity (over an interval).

title: Physics
text:
Problem: Calculating the Velocity Vector
The position function of a particle is given by:
\[ \mathbf{r}(t) = (2.0t^2)\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0t)\hat{j} + (5.0t)\hat{k} \quad (\text{in meters}) \]

What are the instantaneous velocity and speed at \(t = 2.0\) s?
What is the average velocity between \(t = 1.0\) s and \(t = 3.0\) s?


This is a direct application of differentiation to find velocity.
Part (a) tests finding the instantaneous velocity vector and then its magnitude (speed).
Part (b) tests finding the average velocity vector.
These calculations are common in analyzing the motion of objects in engineering systems, such as vehicles, projectiles, or robotic arms.

title: Physics
text:
Velocity Calculation - Solution (a)
(a) Instantaneous velocity and speed at \(t = 2.0\) s:
First, find the velocity vector \(\mathbf{v}(t)\) by differentiating \(\mathbf{r}(t)\):
\[ \mathbf{v}(t) = \frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} = \frac{d}{dt}(2.0t^2)\hat{i} + \frac{d}{dt}(2.0 + 3.0t)\hat{j} + \frac{d}{dt}(5.0t)\hat{k} \] \[ \mathbf{v}(t) = (4.0t)\hat{i} + (3.0)\hat{j} + (5.0)\hat{k} \quad (\text{m/s}) \]
Now, evaluate at \(t = 2.0\) s:
\[ \mathbf{v}(2.0 \text{ s}) = (4.0 \times 2.0)\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \quad (\text{m/s}) \] \[ \mathbf{v}(2.0 \text{ s}) = 8.0\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \quad (\text{m/s}) \]
Speed is the magnitude of the velocity vector:
\[ |\mathbf{v}(2.0 \text{ s})| = \sqrt{(8.0)^2 + (3.0)^2 + (5.0)^2} \quad (\text{m/s}) \] \[ |\mathbf{v}(2.0 \text{ s})| = \sqrt{64 + 9 + 25} = \sqrt{98} \approx 9.9 \text{ m/s} \]

For part (a), we differentiate each term of the position vector component-wise:

\(\frac{d}{dt}(2.0t^2) = 4.0t\)
\(\frac{d}{dt}(2.0 + 3.0t) = 3.0\) (constant terms and linear terms)
\(\frac{d}{dt}(5.0t) = 5.0\)

Then, substitute \(t=2.0\) s into the resulting velocity vector.
Speed is the magnitude, calculated using the 3D Pythagorean theorem.

title: Physics
text:
Velocity Calculation - Solution (b)
(b) Average velocity between \(t = 1.0\) s and \(t = 3.0\) s:
First, find the position vectors at \(t_1 = 1.0\) s and \(t_2 = 3.0\) s:
\[ \mathbf{r}(1.0 \text{ s}) = (2.0(1.0)^2)\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0(1.0))\hat{j} + (5.0(1.0))\hat{k} \] \[ \mathbf{r}(1.0 \text{ s}) = 2.0\hat{i} + 5.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \quad (\text{m}) \]
\[ \mathbf{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) = (2.0(3.0)^2)\hat{i} + (2.0 + 3.0(3.0))\hat{j} + (5.0(3.0))\hat{k} \] \[ \mathbf{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) = (2.0 \times 9.0)\hat{i} + (2.0 + 9.0)\hat{j} + 15.0\hat{k} \] \[ \mathbf{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) = 18.0\hat{i} + 11.0\hat{j} + 15.0\hat{k} \quad (\text{m}) \]
Now, calculate the average velocity:
\[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{\mathbf{r}(3.0 \text{ s}) - \mathbf{r}(1.0 \text{ s})}{3.0 \text{ s} - 1.0 \text{ s}} \] \[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{(18.0\hat{i} + 11.0\hat{j} + 15.0\hat{k}) - (2.0\hat{i} + 5.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k})}{2.0 \text{ s}} \] \[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{(18.0-2.0)\hat{i} + (11.0-5.0)\hat{j} + (15.0-5.0)\hat{k}}{2.0 \text{ s}} \] \[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{16.0\hat{i} + 6.0\hat{j} + 10.0\hat{k}}{2.0 \text{ s}} \] \[ \mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = 8.0\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k} \quad (\text{m/s}) \]
Significance: Interestingly, the average velocity (8.0\(\hat{i}\) + 3.0\(\hat{j}\) + 5.0\(\hat{k}\) m/s) is the same as the instantaneous velocity at \(t = 2.0\) s. This occurs because the velocity vector \(\mathbf{v}(t) = 4.0t\hat{i} + 3.0\hat{j} + 5.0\hat{k}\) is a linear function of time. The instantaneous velocity at the midpoint of the interval (\(t=2.0\)s) equals the average velocity over that interval for linear velocity functions.

For part (b), we first need the position vectors at the start and end times. Substitute \(t=1.0\) s and \(t=3.0\) s into the position equation.
Then, we compute the displacement vector by subtracting the initial position from the final position.
Finally, divide this displacement vector by the time interval (\(3.0 - 1.0 = 2.0\) s).
The significance note points out a special case: when the velocity function is linear, the average velocity over an interval is equal to the instantaneous velocity at the midpoint of that interval. This is a property similar to how the average value of a linear function over an interval is the value at the midpoint.
In general, instantaneous and average velocities are different.

title: Physics
section: Independence of Motion - Example: Projectile Motion
text:
Independence of Motion - Example: Projectile Motion


Consider two baseballs:

One is dropped from rest.
Another is thrown horizontally from the same height at the same instant.

Despite the horizontal motion of the second ball, both balls have identical vertical positions and velocities at every instant in time.
Why?

Horizontal Motion: The horizontally thrown ball has a constant horizontal velocity (assuming no air resistance). There are no horizontal forces acting on it.
Vertical Motion: Both balls experience the same downward acceleration due to gravity. They start with the same initial vertical velocity (zero).

The combination of these independent motions results in the distinct trajectories.


Caption: Figure 4.8 A diagram of the motions of two identical balls: one falls from rest and the other has an initial horizontal velocity. The vertical motions are identical.


This example, often demonstrated with a “monkey gun” apparatus or simulations, visually confirms the independence of motion. The horizontally thrown ball travels a parabolic path. This parabola is the result of its constant horizontal velocity combined with the constant downward acceleration due to gravity. The fact that the vertical motion is unaffected by the horizontal motion is key to analyzing projectile motion. We can calculate the time it takes for the ball to hit the ground using only the vertical information (initial vertical velocity, height, acceleration due to gravity) and then use that time to determine how far it traveled horizontally. This principle is fundamental to fields like ballistics, aerospace engineering, and sports science.

title: Physics
text:
Key Takeaways

Position Vector: \(\mathbf{r}(t) = x(t)\hat{i} + y(t)\hat{j} + z(t)\hat{k}\) describes an object’s location in 2D or 3D space.
Displacement Vector: \(\Delta\mathbf{r} = \mathbf{r}(t_2) - \mathbf{r}(t_1)\) is the straight-line change in position, calculated using vector subtraction.
Instantaneous Velocity: \(\mathbf{v}(t) = \frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt}\) is the rate of change of position, tangent to the path.
Average Velocity: \(\mathbf{v}_{\text{avg}} = \frac{\Delta\mathbf{r}}{\Delta t}\) is displacement divided by time.
Independence of Motion: Perpendicular components of motion (e.g., x and y) can be analyzed separately, simplifying complex trajectories.


These are the core concepts from today’s lecture.
Remember that in physics, “vector” means magnitude AND direction.
Always use vector algebra for displacement and velocity in multiple dimensions.
The independence of motion is a powerful tool for problem-solving, especially in projectile motion.
We’ve covered how to define position, calculate changes in position (displacement), and describe rates of change of position (velocity).
The next step in physics is usually acceleration, which follows similar principles.
